The authors also propose a new evaluation criterion called Perceptual Haus Haus Disturbance ( PHD ) to measure the quality of segmentation results. Experiments are conducted to verify the superiority of the proposed criterion over existing evaluation criteria.

This paper proposes a new benchmark for continual learning ( CL ) based on long streams of tasks. In particular, the authors introduce a new modular architecture, whose modules represent atomic skills that can be composed to perform a certain task. The authors propose a task - driven prior over the exponential search space of all possible ways to combine modules, enabling efficient learning on long - stream tasks. The experiments show that this modular architecture and learning algorithm perform competitively on widely used CL benchmarks while showing superior performance on the more challenging benchmarks.

This paper proposes a generative generative model - based unsupervised meta - learning approach for few - shot classification tasks. The proposed method generates pairs of in - class and out - of - class samples from the latent space in a principled way, allowing us to create synthetic classes forming the training and validation data of a meta - task. The authors show that the proposed approach outperforms or is competitive with current Unsupervised learning baselines on few - shots classification tasks on the most widely used benchmark datasets.

This paper studies the injectivity of fully connected and convolutional ReLU layers and networks. The authors show that an expansivity factor of two is necessary and sufficient for injectivity by constructing appropriate weight matrices. They also characterize the stability of inverting an injective network via worst - case Lipschitz constants of the inverse.

This paper proposes a continuous conditional conditional generative adversarial network ( CcGAN ) for image generation conditional on continuous, scalar conditions ( regression labels ). The authors propose a novel method to incorporate regression labels into the generator and the discriminator. They also propose a new benchmark dataset, RC-49, for generative image modeling conditional on regression labels. They conduct experiments on several datasets and demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a novel query strategy for active learning ( AL ) and semi - supervised learning ( SSL ). The proposed method is based on the neural tangent kernel ( NTK ) and aims to control the convergence rate of a classification network by actively querying instances to improve the rate of convergence upon inclusion to the labeled set. The experiments show that the proposed method can achieve high performance using far less labeled samples than fully supervised learning using fewer labeled data.

This paper proposes a federated learning method for training neural network models, where the server orchestrates cooperation between a subset of randomly chosen devices in each round. The authors point out a fundamental dilemma, in that the minima of the local - device level empirical loss are inconsistent with those of the global empirical loss. They propose a dynamic regularizer for each device at each round, so that in the limit the global and device solutions are aligned. They demonstrate both through empirical results on real and synthetic data as well as analytical results that their scheme leads to efficient training, in both convex and non - convex settings.

This paper proposes a method for accelerating self - supervised learning with little or no loss of accuracy. The main idea is to use intermediate contrastive losses as a surrogate for the final similarity between two pairs of input images. The intermediate losses are used to filter easy regions for each image, which further reduces the computational cost. Experiments show that the proposed method can save the training time with almost no loss on the final performance of the downstream tasks.

This paper studies the global convergence and global optimality of actor - critic with linear function approximation for the first time. In particular, the authors consider two function approximation settings where both the actor and critic are represented by linear or deep neural networks. For both cases, the actor sequence converges to a globally optimal policy at a sublinear O(K+1/2 ) rate.

This paper proposes to represent log data at three levels of abstraction : field level, log level, and log sequence level. The representation for each level can be computed from the previous level. These representations are in vector format and serve as interfaces to downstream applications. The authors use a version of transformer networks (TNs ) to encode numerical and textual information that is suitable for log embeddings.

This paper proposes a new formalism for decomposing convolutional layers into wavelet decompositions, which are modulated by mixture weights. The proposed method is based on the dual - tree wavelet packet transform ( DT - CWPT ), which is similar to oriented Gabor filters in the sense that it is well - localized in the frequency domain and share a subsampling factor over the output feature maps. Experiments show that the proposed method achieves the accuracy rate of standard AlexNet but with a significantly lower number of parameters.

This paper proposes a coach - player framework for dynamic team composition of heterogeneous agents in multi - agent particle environments. The authors assume that the players only have a partial view of the environment, while the coach has a complete view. They propose an attention mechanism for both the players and the coach, incorporate a variational objective to regularize learning, and design an adaptive communication method to let the coach decide when to communicate with different players. They apply their methods on resource - collection tasks in Multi - Agent particle environments and demonstrate zero - shot generalization for new team compositions at test time.

This paper provides a large - scale empirical study of the performance of influence functions in neural network models trained on datasets such as Iris, MNIST, CIFAR-10 and ImageNet. The results show that the accuracy of influence estimates can vary significantly depending on the examined test points. The paper also shows that for certain network architectures and datasets, training with weight - decay regularization is important to get high - quality influence estimates.

This paper studies the connection between the pretraining task of next word prediction and the downstream task of text classification. In particular, the authors propose to formalize the connection and quantify the benefit of language modeling. Theoretically, they show that classification tasks of interest can be reformulated as sentence completion tasks, thus making language modeling meaningful pretraining tasks. Theorem 4.2 shows a stronger result for low - dimensional softmax models by leveraging a new tool, conditional mean features ( definition 4.1 ), which is shown to be effective in practice.

This paper proposes a new method for membership inference attacks ( MIA ) based on reconstruction error. The main idea is to use the reconstruction error as a proxy for the difficulty score to measure the difficulty of a given image. The difficulty score is computed by subtracting reconstruction error from the reconstruction score. The method is evaluated on an extensive number of benchmarks demonstrating its effectiveness compared to strong baseline methods.

This paper proposes a differentiable neural architecture search method by formulating it into a distribution learning problem. The authors treat the continuously relaxed architecture mixing weight as random variables, modeled by Dirichlet distribution, and propose a progressive learning scheme that enables searching directly on large - scale tasks. Extensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new method for function approximators for low - dimensional but complex functions. The proposed method is based on multiplicative filter networks ( MFNs ) that simply multiply together linear functions of sinusoidal or Gabor wavelet functions applied to the input. The authors show that the proposed method performs as well or better than the previously proposed SIREN or Fourier feature networks. They also show that MFNs achieve better performance deltas.

This paper proposes a simple yet effective method for gradient - based meta - learning. The key idea is to employ a student network to adequately explore the search space of task - specific models ( e.g. by more than ten steps ) and a teacher then takes a “leap ” toward the regions probed by the student to arrive at a high - quality model but also defines a lightweight computation graph for meta - gradients. The proposed method is evaluated on few - shot learning, long - tailed classification, and meta - attack tasks.

This paper proposes a new algorithm for offline reinforcement learning ( D4RL ) based on behavior regularization ( BRAC+ ). The main idea is to use an analytical upper bound on KL divergence as the behavior regularizor to reduce variance associated with sample based estimations. Additionally, the authors propose state - dependent Lagrange multipliers for the regularization term to avoid distributing distributing KL divergence penalty across all states of the sampled batch. Experiments show that the proposed algorithm outperforms existing state - of - the - art model - free and model - based offline RL algorithms.

This paper proposes a new training method for compressing and regularizing CNN - based deep neural networks. The proposed method trains both the original and the smaller networks together, where the parameters of the smaller network are shared across both the larger and smaller networks.   The authors prove strong theoretical guarantees on the regularization behavior of the proposed method. They also conduct extensive empirical evaluation of both the compression and regularization behaviour of adjoint networks. For resnet-50 trained adjointly on Imagenet, they are able to achieve a 13.7x reduction in the number of parameters and a 5x improvement in inference time.

This paper proposes an exploration algorithm that retains the simplicity of greedy while reducing dithering. The main limitation of greedy exploration is its lack of temporal persistence, which limits its ability to escape local optima. The authors propose a temporally extended form of - greedy that simply repeats the sampled action for a random duration. It turns out that, for many duration distributions, this suffices to improve exploration on a large set of domains.

This paper studies the implicit regularization of gradient flow in matrix factorization. In particular, the authors show that for depth-2 matrix factorisation, gradient flow with infinitesimal initialization is mathematically equivalent to Greedy Low - Rank Learning ( GLRL ) under some reasonable assumptions. The authors also extend their results to deep matrix factoriziation Section 6, where they prove that the trajectory of GF with identity initialization converges to a deep version of GLRL at least in the early stage of the optimization.

This paper proposes a two - stage model patching method for improving robustness to spurious bandages. The first stage is to model subgroup features within a class and learn semantic transformations between them, and then train a classifier with data augmentations that deliberately manipulate sub group features. The second stage trains with a CycleGAN to learn the intra - class, inter - subgroup augmentations, and balances subgroup performance using a theoretically -motivated subgroup consistency objective. The proposed method is evaluated on three benchmark datasets, with reductions in robust error of up to 33 % relative to the best baseline.

This paper proposes a novel method for rule - based representation learning based on continuous features. The main idea is to use gradient descent to optimize the discrete model using gradient descent. The proposed method is evaluated on 9 small and 4 large data sets. The experimental results show that the proposed method outperforms competitive baselines.

This paper proposes a new regret minimization algorithm and its extension for structured environments. The proposed method builds from invariant risk minimization ( IRM ) by recasting simultaneous optimality condition in terms of predictive regret. The extension adaptively highlights variation due to complex environments via specialized domain perturbations. The experiments show that the proposed method outperforms previous state - of - the - art baselines on three applications : molecular property prediction, protein homology and stability prediction.

This paper proposes a novel architecture, cross - probe ( CP BERT ) BERT, for text - vision BERT retrieval. It relies on devised text and vision probes, and the cross - modal attentions are conducted on text and image probes. It takes lightweight computation cost, and meanwhile effectively exploits crossmodal attention. Systematic experiments conducted on two public benchmarks demonstrate the effectiveness and efficiency of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new type of actor named forward - looking actor ( FORK ) for Actor - Critic algorithms. The proposed FORK can be easily integrated into a model - free ActorCritic algorithm. The experiments on six Box2D and MuJoCo environments with continuous state and action spaces demonstrate significant performance improvement for FORK compared to the state - of - the - art Actor - critic algorithms.

This paper proposes a new federated learning ( FL ) algorithm that aggregates local models into a global model by sampling higher - quality global models and combining them via Bayesian model Ensemble. The authors show that an effective model distribution can be constructed by simply fitting a Gaussian or Dirichlet distribution to the local models. The empirical studies validate FEDBE ’s superior performance, especially when users ’ data are not i.i.d. and when the neural networks go deeper.

This paper presents a new method for estimating BERT under double - blind conditions. The paper is well - written and easy to follow. The main contribution of the paper is a detailed description of the methodology and a detailed analysis of the BERT model. The authors also provide a detailed discussion of the limitations of the proposed method and provide an extensive comparison to related work.

This paper provides a priori finite - time convergence analysis of deep neural networks in the control theory setting. The authors formulate the supervised learning framework as a control problem where weights of the network are control inputs and learning translates into a tracking problem. An analytical formula for finite time upper bound on the settling time is provided under the assumptions of boundedness of input and bounded perturbations. Finally, the authors prove that their loss function is robust against input perturbation.

This paper studies the problem of disentangling latent variables in the context of nonlinear independent component analysis ( ICA ). In this paper, the authors propose to use the mutual information between learned latent variables and auxiliary variables to identify informative latent variables. The proposed method is tested on classification, outlier detection, and adversarial attack defence on both synthetic and real data.

This paper proposes two new pooling operations for convolutional neural networks. The first one is called LiftDownPool, which decomposes a feature map into various downsized sub - bands, each of which contains information with different frequencies. The second one is named LiftUpPool and consists of two pooling layers, one for downsampling the feature map and one for up - pooling. Experiments show that the proposed method outperforms baselines on image classification and semantic segmentation.

This paper proposes a fast, distance - preserving, binary embedding algorithm to transform a high - dimensional dataset T into binary sequences in the cube {±1}. When T consists of well - spread ( i.e., non - sparse ) vectors, this embedding method applies a stable noise - shaping quantization scheme to Ax where A is a sparse Gaussian random matrix. The authors show that Euclidean distances among the elements of T are approximated by the `1 norm on the images of T under a fast linear transformation. This contrasts with standard methods, where the Hamming distance is used instead.

This paper proposes a method to learn plasticity rules for the weights of recurrent neural networks ( RNNs ) based on gradient descent ( GD ). The main idea is that the plasticity rule is learned by gradient descent on the parameters of the RNN and can be used to improve robustness and generalization of the network to adversarial perturbations. The authors provide both empirical and theoretical evidence for this hypothesis. The experiments show that the proposed method is able to generalize to synthetic data and converge to a good classifier faster.

This paper proposes a new method for visual question generation ( VQG ) based on Graph - to - Sequence learning ( GTS ). The key idea is to use double - hint visual hints to generate visual questions with answer - aware and region - reference. The proposed method is evaluated on the VQA2.0 and COCO - QA datasets and is shown to outperform existing state - of - the - art methods.

This paper studies the phenomenon of " double descent ", i.e., non - monotonic test performance of linear regression models with isotropic data distribution. The authors show that optimally - tuned `2 regularization can mitigate double descent for more general models, including neural networks. Theoretically, the authors prove that for certain linear regressors, optimally tuned $ \ell_2$ regularization achieves monotony test performance as we grow either the sample size or the model size. Empirically, they show that the optimality of the regularization helps mitigate the double descent phenomenon.

This paper proposes a spatial dependency network ( SDN ) to improve generative modeling by exploiting spatial regularities and coherence in images. The spatial dependency networks ( SDNs ) compute feature maps at each level of a deep neural net are computed in a spatially coherent way, using a sequential gating - based mechanism that distributes contextual information across 2 - D space. Experiments are conducted in two different settings : real - life - image density modeling and synthetic data.

This paper proposes a simplified version of BCQ ( Fujimoto et al., 2018a ) for offline RL. The main idea is to remove a heuristic design choice and naturally restrict extracted policies to remain exactly within the support of a given behavior policy. The authors derive a novel backup operator, Expected - Max Q - Learning ( EMaQ ), which is more closely related to the resulting practical algorithm. In the offline RL setting, the proposed method matches and outperforms prior state - of - the - art in the D4RL benchmarks ( Fu et al., 2020a ) and surpasses Soft Actor Critic ( SAC ) in the deployment - efficient setting ( Matsushima et al, 2020 ).

This paper proposes a batch selection algorithm for improving model fairness in machine learning models. The proposed algorithm is based on batch optimization with an outer optimizer that selects batch sizes for the purpose of improving the fairness of the model. The paper also proposes three fairness measures : equal opportunity, equalized odds, and demographic parity. Experiments are conducted on synthetic and benchmark real data.

This paper studies the bounds on the Lipschitz constant of monDEQs, a recently proposed subclass of deep DEQs. The authors show that monotone deep equilibrium ( DEQ ) models can be bounded as a function of the strong monotonicity parameter of the network. They derive simple - yet - tight bounds on both the input - output mapping and the weight -output mapping defined by these networks, and demonstrate that they are small relative to those for comparable standard DNNs. They also highlight how to use these bounds to develop PAC - Bayes generalization bounds that do not depend on the depth of the networks and avoid the exponential depth - dependence of comparable DNN bounds.

This paper proposes a method for imitation learning and goal - conditioned reinforcement learning. The main idea is to use density estimation to estimate the density of expert states that the agent is likely to visit and then use a value - function to guide the agent towards those states. The paper shows that the proposed method is able to learn from extremely sparse amounts of expert data and achieves state - of - the - art results on a common benchmark.

This paper proposes a new framework for multi - task learning based on variational Bayesian inference. The main idea is to introduce Gumbel - softmax priors to condition the prior of each task on related tasks. Each prior is represented as a mixture of variational posteriors of other related tasks and the mixing weights are learned in a data - driven manner for each individual task. The posteriors over representations and classifiers are inferred jointly for all tasks and individual tasks are able to improve their performance by using the shared inductive bias.

This paper proposes a systematic and unified benchmark, Long - Range Arena, for evaluating model quality under long - range scenarios. The benchmark is a suite of tasks consisting of sequences ranging from 1K to 16K tokens, encompassing a wide range of data types and modalities such as text, natural, synthetic images, and mathematical expressions requiring similarity, structural similarity, and visual - spatial reasoning. The paper systematically evaluates ten well - established long range Transformer models ( Reformers, Linformers, Linear Transformers, Sinkhorn Transformers, Performers, Synthesizers, Sparse Transformers, and Longformers ) on the newly proposed benchmark suite.

This paper proposes a multilingual code summarization model that jointly learns on Context and Structure of source code. The model uses only language - agnostic features, i.e., source code and features that can be computed directly from the AST. Experiments show that training on non - parallel data from multiple programming languages improves results on all individual languages. The strongest gains are on low - resource languages.

This paper proposes a new approach for audio - visual navigation in which an agent navigates through a complex 3D environment using both sights and sounds to find a sound source ( e.g., a phone ringing in another room ). The key idea is to learn a set of waypoints that are dynamically set and learned end - to - end within the navigation policy and an acoustic memory that provides a structured, spatially grounded record of what the agent has heard as it moves. The proposed approach is evaluated on two challenging datasets of real - world 3D scenes, Replica and Matterport3D. It outperforms the state - of - the - art for AudioGoal navigation by a substantial margin and generalizes much better to the challenging cases of unheard sounds.

This paper studies the convergence of small convolutional networks on Conway ’s Game of Life. The authors show that networks trained on this task require substantially more parameters to consistently converge. They also show that the initialization parameters that gradient descent converges to a solution are sensitive to small perturbations. Finally, they observe a critical value d0 such that training minimal networks with examples in which cells are alive with probability d0 dramatically increases the chance of convergence.

This paper proposes a new objective function called BatchMean Triplet loss ( BMTL ) for semi - supervised learning ( SSL ). The proposed objective is based on the observation that the inputs having the same label should have the similar model outputs. The method is simple yet effective, achieving state - of - the - art results across many standard SSL benchmarks with labeled data amounts.

This paper studies the problem of few - shot meta - learning in a sequential learning setting, where tasks are presented in sequence. The authors propose a new meta - training algorithm that can adapt to variable amounts of data and an online version of this algorithm that addresses the problem setting of online incremental learning. They theoretically derive their algorithm and combine it with deep neural networks for effective online learning on challenging sequential problem settings. They find that their approach can outperform empirical risk minimization and a previous online meta - learner method on two online image classification problems consisting of sequences of classification tasks and one online regression problem. They also show that the approach performs comparably to previous state - of - the - art algorithms in the offline setting and provides considerable gains in the variable - shot setting.

This paper presents a series of experiments to evaluate the sensitivity of pre - trained Transformer representations to syntactic structure in sentences. The experiments are based on the notion of representational invariance, which is derived from computational and cognitive neuroscience. Each probe involves swapping words in a sentence and comparing the representations from perturbed sentences against the original. The results suggest that Transformers build sensitivity to larger parts of the sentence along their layers, and that hierarchical phrase structure plays a role in this process.

This paper studies the few - shot image synthesis task for GAN with minimum computing cost. The authors propose a light - weight GAN structure that gains superior quality on 1024 × 1024 resolution. The model converges from scratch with just a few hours of training on a single RTX-2080 GPU and has a consistent performance, even with less than 100 training samples.

This paper proposes a novel dual dual algorithm for neural network bounding. The main idea is to use a small set of dual variables to recover the strengths of the new relaxation in the dual space : tightness and a linear separation oracle. The authors show that the proposed method is competitive with dual approaches on the looser relaxation ( Dvijotham et al. 2018 ) and yields tighter bounds if a larger computational budget is available.

This paper proposes a method to augment pre - trained language models ( PTLMs ) with concept - centric commonsense knowledge. The authors propose both generative and contrastive objectives for learning common sense from the text, and use them as intermediate self - supervised learning tasks for incrementally pre - training PTLM ( before task - specific fine - tuning on downstream datasets ). Extensive experimental results show that the proposed method outperforms baseline methods by a consistent margin and even comparable with some larger models on four commonsense - related NLU datasets.

This paper studies the problem of unsupervised physical object discovery from video. In particular, the authors propose a network that uses both multi - scale pixel cues and physical motion cues to accurately segment observable and partially occluded objects of varying sizes, and infer properties of those objects. The discovered object properties can also be used to reason about physical events ( Smith et al. 2019 ).

This paper proposes a method to improve the robustness of deep neural networks ( DNNs ) against white - box adversarial attacks. Specifically, the proposed method increases the margins of training samples by moving the decision boundaries of the DNN model far away from the training samples to improve robustness. The proposed method is evaluated on six publicly available datasets ( including a COVID - 19 CT image dataset ) under strong 100 - PGD white box attacks. The results show that the method significantly improved classification accuracy on noisy data.

This paper proposes a model - agnostic method for knowledge distillation, where intermediate targets are constructed by a model with the same architecture of teacher and trained by approximate mirror descent. The proposed method could be less sensitive with the quirks during optimization which could result in a better local optima. Experiments on both image and text datasets show that the proposed ProKT consistently achieves the state - of - the - art performance comparing to all existing knowledge distillations methods.

This paper proposes a novel channel pruning method to solve the problem of compression and acceleration of convolutional neural networks ( CNNs ). The proposed method uses a hyper - structure network to generate the architecture of the main network and a regularization term to specify the computational resource of the compact network. Extensive experiments on CIFAR-10 and ImageNet show that the proposed method is competitive with state - of - the - art methods and auto - ML based pruning methods.

This paper presents a method for learning a theorem prover trained on a large knowledge base of potential premises without learning from human proofs. The method is based on a simple tf - idf ( term frequency - inverse document frequency ) based lookup in a deep reinforcement learning scenario. The experiments show that the method outperforms provers that are trained only on human proofs and approaches the performance of a prover training by a combination of imitation and reinforcement learning.

This paper proposes an automated data augmentation approach called MODALS ( Modalityagnostic Automated Data Augmentation in the Latent Space ) to augment data for any modality in a generic way. The proposed approach fine - tune four universal data transformation operations in the latent space to adapt the transform to data of different modalities. Experiments are conducted on multiple datasets for text, tabular, time - series and image modalities to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

This paper studies the mean field limit of three - layer neural networks under stochastic gradient descent training. The authors prove a global convergence result for unregularized feedforward three - layers networks in the mean - field regime. The result is a universal approximation property, natural of neural networks, which importantly is shown to hold at any finite training time ( not necessarily at convergence ) via an algebraic topology argument.

This paper proposes a method for learning explanations of expert decisions by modeling their reward function in terms of preferences with respect to “ what if ” outcomes. To learn these cost - benefit tradeoffs associated with the expert ’s actions, the authors integrate counterfactual reasoning into batch inverse reinforcement learning. Experiments show the effectiveness of the proposed method in recovering accurate and interpretable descriptions of expert behavior.

This paper studies the problem of continuous control in a graph - based continuous control setting. The authors propose a message - passing method based on graph neural networks ( GNNs ) that use the physical morphology of the agent to construct the input graph and use edges to connect the nodes if their corresponded limbs are physically connected. The proposed method is evaluated on the MTRL continuous control benchmark and shows superior performance compared to existing methods.

This paper proposes a novel method for visual counting. The method is based on revisiting modulated convolutions that fuse the query and the image locally. The proposed method is called MoVie, short for Modulated ConVolutional Bottlenecks. The paper shows that the proposed method outperforms the state - of - the - art on counting - specific VQA tasks while being more efficient. It also outperforms prior work on difficult benchmarks like COCO for common object counting.

This paper proposes a model - targeted poisoning attack based on online convex optimization. The authors prove that the model induced by training on the original training data with these points added, converges to the target classifier as the number of poison points increases, given that the loss function is convex and proper regularization is adopted in training. They also provide a lower bound on the minimum number of poisoning points needed to reach the target model ( Theorem 4.2 ).

This paper proposes a binarization approach for efficient deep learning on point clouds. The main contribution of the paper is two - fold. First, the authors identify two main reasons for performance drop : aggregation - induced feature homogenization that leads to a degradation of information entropy, and scale distortion that hinders optimization and invalidates scale - sensitive structures. Second, they introduce an entropy - maximizing aggregation ( EMA ) to modulate the distribution before aggregation for the maximum information entropy and layer - wise scale recovery ( LSR ) to efficiently restore feature representation capacity. Extensive experiments show that the proposed method outperforms existing binarized methods by convincing margins.

This paper proposes to augment the Transformer model with memory to selectively store local and global representations of a sequence of words. The idea is to use memory tokens to store non - local representations, creating a memory bottleneck for the global information, controlling memory update with dedicated layer. Experiments show that the presence of memory improves the model performance for machine translation and language modelling tasks.

This paper proposes a method for contrastive learning with clustering. Specifically, the authors introduce prototypes as latent variables to help find the maximum - likelihood estimation of the network parameters in an Expectation - Maximization framework. The authors also propose ProtoNCE loss to encourage representations to be closer to their assigned prototypes. Experiments show that the proposed method outperforms state - of - the - art methods on multiple benchmarks.

This paper proposes a method to defend against adversarial attacks by using multiple paths to learn robust features. The parameters of these paths are required to be orthogonal with each other. The proposed method uses forward learning and backward correction to learn features that are appropriate for all the paths and hence are expected to be robust. Experiments show that the proposed method can defend against white - box and black - box attacks.

This paper proposes a self - supervised graph attention network ( SuperGAT ) for noisy graphs. Specifically, the authors exploit two attention forms compatible with the self - supervision task to predict edges, whose presence and absence contain the inherent information about the importance of the relationships between nodes. By encoding edges, the proposed network learns more expressive attention in distinguishing mislinked neighbors. The authors also analyze the classic attention forms GO and DP using label - agreement and link prediction tasks.

This paper proposes a new approach to improve the reliability and robustness of the dialogue system for medical automatic diagnosis ( DSMAD ). The approach is based on the introspective decision - making process of human doctors, where the inquiry module first proposes the most valuable symptom inquiry, then the introspection module intervenes the potential responses of this inquiry and decides to inquire only if the diagnoses of these interventions vary. Extensive experimental results demonstrate that the proposed approach achieves the new state - of - the - art under various experimental settings.

This paper proposes a batch - wise regularization method for fine - grained and long - tailed visual classification ( FGVC ). The proposed method is based on a batch norm - based framework with sufficient model capacity to simultaneously deal with FGVC and long tailed issues at the same time. The experimental results show that the proposed method achieves state - of - the - art results on several benchmark FGVC datasets.

This paper proposes a new method for offline inverse reinforcement learning ( IRL ). The main idea is to jointly learn an approximate posterior distribution over the reward that scales to arbitrarily complicated state spaces alongside an appropriate policy in a completely offline manner through a variational approach to the latent reward. The method is applied to real medical data alongside classic control simulations. The results show that the proposed method can achieve Bayesian reward inference in such settings.

This paper proposes a method for learning counterfactual belief distributions for partially observable environments. The key idea is to use an approximate auto - regressive belief distribution that is learned as a supervised task in multi - agent settings. The method is evaluated on Hanabi in the benchmark domain of two player Hanabi self - play, where the exact belief distribution would be prohibitively expensive.

This paper proposes a novel method for planning in large state spaces. The proposed method is based on an interpolation between MCTS and random shooting. The authors show that the proposed method can get the best of both worlds consistently achieving higher scores in experiments on challenging domains. The paper is well written and easy to follow.

This paper proposes a method for learning inductive bias from synthetic datasets. The authors propose a new pre - training methodology called “ LIME ” ( Learning Inductive bias for Mathematical rEasoning ). The method is based on the observation that deduction, induction, and abduction form an irreducible set of reasoning primitives, and the authors design three synthetic tasks that are intended to require the model to have these three abilities. The synthetic tasks are designed in a way that they are devoid of mathematical knowledge to ensure that only the fundamental reasoning biases can be learned from these tasks. Models trained with LIME outperform vanilla transformers on three very different large mathematical reasoning benchmarks.

This paper studies the inductive bias of gradient descent for weight normalized smooth homogeneous neural nets, when trained on exponential or cross - entropy loss. The main result is that the gradient flow path with exponential weight normalization ( EWN ) is equivalent to gradient flow on standard networks with an adaptive learning rate, and hence causes the weights to be updated in a way that prefers asymptotic relative sparsity. These results can be extended to hold for gradient descent via an appropriate learning rate.

This paper studies the mode collapse problem in generative adversarial networks ( GANs ) and proposes a novel training procedure that dynamically spawns additional discriminators to remember previous modes of generation. The proposed method is evaluated on several datasets and is shown to improve standard metrics for GAN evaluation.

This paper proposes a method to regularize BERT by pruning its attention heads based on a proxy score for head importance. Instead of relying on heuristics or rule - based policies, the proposed method learns a pruning policy that determines which attention heads should or should not be pruned for regularization. Experimental results show that AUBER outperforms existing pruning methods by achieving up to 9.39 % better accuracy.

This paper proposes a method for learning correspondence between simulated and real robotic environments. The method is based on the MuJoCo physics engine and aims to align two domains across different modalities, physical parameters, and morphologies. The authors propose a cycle consistency constraint to align dynamic robot behavior across two domains using a cycle - consistency constraint. Once this correspondence is found, the method can directly transfer the policy trained on one domain to the other without needing any additional fine - tuning on the second domain.

This paper studies the problem of Shapley explainability in the context of machine learning. The authors propose two solutions to the problem, one based on generative modelling and the other on Shapley value - function learning.   The main contribution of the paper is to demonstrate the drawbacks of the assumption that the features of the model are uncorrelated, which is an untenable assumption under the Shapley framework for explainability.

This paper proposes a new method for opponent modelling based on variational autoencoders to reconstruct the local actions and observations of the opponent based on embeddings which depend only on the local observations. The proposed method is evaluated in two benchmark environments used in multi - agent systems research, the multi -agent particle environment and level - based foraging ( LBF ). The results show that the proposed method achieves comparable performance to an ideal baseline which has full access to opponent ’s information, and significantly higher returns than a baseline method which does not use the learned embedding.

This paper proposes Consistent Contrast ( CO2 ), which introduces a consistency regularization term into the current contrastive learning framework by taking the similarity of the query crop to each crop from other images as a pseudo label, and encourages consistency between these two similarities. The proposed method improves Momentum Contrast ( MoCo ) by 2.9 % on top - 1 accuracy on ImageNet linear protocol, 3.8 % and 1.1 % top - 5 accuracy on 1% and 10 % labeled semi - supervised settings. It also transfers to image classification, object detection, and semantic segmentation on PASCAL VOC.

This paper studies the last - iterate convergence of Optimistic Gradient Descent Ascent Descent ( OGDA ) and Optimistic Multiplicative Weights Update ( OMWU ) for bilinear games over the probability simplex. The main contribution of this work is the introduction of a sufficient condition under which OGDA exhibits concrete last -iterate convergence rates with a constant learning rate whose value only depends on the smoothness of the objective function. Experimental results are also provided to support the theory.

This paper proposes a federated user verification ( UV ) model training framework for federated federated settings. The key idea is to learn a set of vectors and maximize the correlation of their instance embeddings with a secret user - defined linear combination of those vectors. The proposed method is evaluated on voice, face, and handwriting recognition datasets. The results show that FedUV outperforms FedAwS while not sharing the embedding vectors with the server.

This paper proposes a method to estimate the effective dimension of class manifolds ( CMs ) and the boundaries between multiple CMs by computing their intersection with random affine subspaces of varying dimension. The authors provide a theory for the technique and verify that their theoretical predictions agree with measurements on real neural networks. Through extensive experiments, they leverage this method to show deep connections between the geometry of CMs, generalization, and robustness to show that robust models have higher dimensional CMs than worse performing models.

This paper proposes a novel method to improve the trade - off between exploration and exploitation in reinforcement learning ( RL ). The main idea is that the agent should explore more in an unfamiliar state, while less in a familiar state, so as to understand the environment more efficiently. To this purpose, the authors propose Curiosity - Aware Entropy Temperature for Soft Actor - Critic ( CAT - SAC ), which utilizes the curiosity mechanism in developing an instance - level entropy temperature. The experiments show that the proposed method significantly improves the sample efficiency on the MuJoCo benchmark.

This paper proposes a meta - reinforcement learning algorithm for out - of - distribution ( OOD ) tasks. The proposed method is based on the observation that dynamics models can be adapted efficiently and consistently with off - policy data, more easily than policies and value functions for OOD tasks. To this end, the authors propose a model identification and experience relabeling ( MIER ) algorithm that is both efficient and extrapolates well when faced with out of distribution tasks at test time. Experiments are collected from other tasks during meta - training, by using the learned model to relabel the next state and reward on every previously seen transition.

This paper studies the few - shot learning ( FSL ) problem with sampling noise and label noise. The authors propose a method called Eigen - Reptile ( ER ) that updates the meta - parameters with the main direction of historical taskspecific parameters to alleviate gradient noise. They also propose Introspective Self - paced Learning ( ISPL ) that constructs a plurality of prior models to determine which sample should be abandoned in FSL. The proposed method is evaluated theoretically and experimentally on several tasks.

This paper proposes a method for robust training against distributional shifts in the mean and variance of deep image features. The proposed method is based on batch normalization ( AdvBN ), which is a regularization of the feature statistics to produce models that are robust to distributional shift. Experiments on ImageNet-C, Stylized - ImageNet, and ImageNetInstagram show that the proposed method significantly improves the performance of ResNet-50 on these tasks.

This paper proposes a metric called Variance of Gradients ( VoG ) as a proxy metric for detecting outliers in the data distribution. The authors provide quantitative and qualitative support that VoG is a meaningful way to rank data by difficulty and to surface a tractable subset of the most challenging examples for human - in - the - loop auditing. Data points with high VoG scores are far more difficult for the model to learn and over - index on corrupted or memorized examples.

This paper proposes a new method to improve the quality of generated samples in deep generative models. The proposed method is based on gradient flow of entropy - regularized f - divergences between the real and the generated data distributions. The gradient flow takes the form of a non - linear Fokker - plank equation, which can be easily simulated by sampling from the equivalent McKean - Vlasov process. Experiments show that the proposed method outperforms the state - of - the - art Discriminator Optimal Transport ( DOT ) and Discriminators Driven Latent Sampling ( DDLS ) methods.

This paper presents a pre - training approach for multilingual Transformer models that unifies the two mainstreams in both model architectures and tasks. The approach splits the standard Transformer block into several sub - modules trained with both innersequence and cross - sequence masked language modeling, and reorganizes certain sub - module for understanding and generation tasks during inference. The proposed approach outperforms all existing cross - lingual models and state - of - the - art Transformer variants on WMT14 English to German and English to French translation datasets with gains of up to 1∼2 BLEU.

This paper proposes a novel intrinsic reward for reinforcement learning that encourages the agent to understand the causal effect of its actions through auditory event prediction. First, the agent collects a small amount of acoustic data and uses K - means to discover underlying auditory event clusters and then train a neural network to predict the auditory events and use the prediction errors as intrinsic rewards to guide RL exploration. The authors conduct an in - depth analysis of their module using a set of Atari games and apply it to audio - visual exploration using the Habitat simulator and active learning using the ThreeDWorld simulator.

This paper studies the problem of novel category discovery on single and multimodal data with labels from different but relevant categories. The authors propose a generic, end - to - end framework to jointly learn a reliable representation and assign clusters to unlabelled data. To avoid over - fitting the learnt embedding to labelled data, they take inspiration from self - supervised representation learning by noise - contrastive estimation and extend it to jointly handle labelled and unlabelling data. They also employ Winner - Take - All ( WTA ) hashing algorithm on the shared representation space to generate pairwise pseudo labels to better predict cluster assignments.

This paper studies the weakly supervised segmentation task, where the task is to assign a label to every pixel based on training instances with partial annotations such as image - level tags, object bounding boxes, labeled points and scribbles. This task is challenging, as coarse annotations ( tags, boxes ) lack precise pixel localization whereas sparse annotations ( points, scribbles ) lack broad region coverage. The authors propose 4 types of contrastive relationships between pixels and segments in the feature space, capturing low - level image similarity, semantic annotation, co - occurrence, feature affinity, and feature affinity. They also formulate the task as a semi - supervised metric learning problem, where pixels of the same ( different ) semantics need to be mapped to same (distinctive ) features.

This paper proposes a simple but effective distillation strategy for unsupervised learning. The key idea is that the relationship among similar samples counts and can be seamlessly transferred to the student to boost the performance. BINGO achieves new state - of - the - art performance on small scale models, i.e., 65.5 % and 68.9 % top - 1 accuracies with linear evaluation on ImageNet.

This paper proposes a new approach for simulation - based inference ( SBI ). The main idea is to reformulate the variational objective in an adversarial setting to learn implicit posterior distributions. The proposed approach is evaluated on two SBI benchmark problems and on two high - dimensional simulators. On a model for wave propagation on the surface of a shallow water body, the proposed approach can return well - calibrated posterior estimates even in high dimensions.

This paper studies the identification and estimation of individualized treatment effects under limited overlap ( TEs ). Specifically, the authors propose a generative model that recovers prognostic scores from observed variables and uses them to identify individualized TEs. The model is then learned as a new type of variational autoencoder ( VAE ) and the TE error bounds are derived. The proposed method is compared with recent methods using ( semi-)synthetic datasets using (semi - synthetic datasets ).

This paper proposes a benchmark for autonomous reinforcement learning ( ARL ). The benchmark is based on a modified version of an existing benchmark for reset - free RL. The main contribution of the paper is the formalization of ARL as an autonomous RL problem. The paper also provides a number of instantiations of the ARL problem, such as irreversible states, interventions, and other components.

This paper investigates the reasoning capability of existing Graph Neural Networks ( GNNs ) for knowledge - aware QA. The authors show that existing GNN - based modules can only carry out some simple reasoning such as counting. They also show that even a very simple graph neural counter can outperform all the existing modules on CommonsenseQA and OpenBookQA.

This paper proposes a new compression method for Deep Neural Networks ( DNN ) inference. The main idea is to use the Succinct Data Structures ( SDS ) to compress the representation of DNN models. The proposed method first transforms the DNN model in either an Element - wise or Block - wise manner. Then, a pipeline is used to retrieve the relevant data for DNN inference. Experiments show that the proposed method achieves near - optimal compression.

This paper proposes a new training method for improving the performance of tiny neural networks. The authors argue that training tiny models is different from training large models, and that instead of augmenting the data, we should augment the model, since tiny models tend to suffer from under - fitting rather than over - fitting due to limited capacity. To alleviate this issue, the authors propose to augment the network ( reverse dropout ) instead of inserting noise into the dataset or the network. It puts the tiny model into larger models and encourages it to work as a sub - model of larger models.

This paper proposes a super - resolution generative adversarial network ( GAN ) for dynamic point cloud sequences without requiring point correspondence annotation. The proposed method learns the underlying temporal coherence from point cloud sequence, which in turn guides the generator to produce temporally coherent output. A learnable masking module is also proposed to adapt upsampling ratio according to the point distribution. Experiments are conducted on two different domains : particles in the fluid dynamical system and human action scanned data.

This paper proposes a new method for fully pre - training object detection transformers. The main idea is to use a task adapter to train the encoder - only transformer and finetune it for object detection. The proposed method achieves competitive performance on the challenging COCO dataset ( Lin et al. 2014 ).

This paper proposes FedPAGE, a new federated local gradient descent method for convex and nonconvex optimization. The main idea is to use the recent optimal PAGE method to further reduce the communication complexity. The proposed method achieves new theoretical state - of - the - art results in terms of communication complexity for both federated conve x and non - convex optimization settings.

This paper proposes to define a subspace of adversarial directions of orthogonal directions of minimal perturbation to the decision boundary from any given input sample in the adversarial subspace. The authors show that adversarial training increases the distance to the boundary distance in the entire adversarial space. The main contribution of this work is to further our understanding of decision boundary geometry of ANN classifiers by utilizing such adversarial perturbations.

This paper proposes a two - stage weakly - supervised contrastive learning approach. The first stage is to cluster data according to its auxiliary information and the second stage to learn similar representations within the same cluster and dissimilar representations for data from different clusters. The authors conduct experiments on learning visual representations using UT - zappos50k ( Yu & Grauman, 2014 ), CUB - 200 - 2011, Wider Attribute ( Li et al. 2016 ) and ImageNet - 100 datasets. The results show that the auxiliary - information - infused representations, compared to conventional self - supervised representations, have a much better performance on downstream tasks.

This paper studies the problem of estimating sparse parameters from observational data. The authors propose a method to learn algorithms automatically from data by unrolling a classic path - following algorithm, with some components being more flexible and learnable. With this structure, they theoretically show the improved recovery accuracy achievable by PLISA. Furthermore, they analyze the empirical Rademacher complexity of PLISA to characterize its generalization ability to solve new problems outside the training set.

This paper proposes a method to learn a compact and decodable latent representation space for the original discrete - continuous hybrid action space. The proposed method constructs the latent space and embeds the dependence between discrete action and continuous parameter via an embedding table and conditional conditional Variational Auto - Encoder ( VAE ). Finally, the agent learns its policy with conventional DRL algorithms in the learned representation space and interacts with the environment by decoding the hybrid action embeddings to the original action space in a variety of environments. The results demonstrate the superiority of HyAR when compared with previous baselines.

This paper proposes a new algorithm for nonconvex stochastic gradient descent with energy and momentum. The proposed algorithm is based on the AEGD algorithm, which is a generalization of the energy - based gradient descent method. The authors show that the proposed algorithm converges faster and generalizes as well as SGDM in the online convex setting. The paper also provides a regret bound for the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new model for non - autoregressive machine translation ( NAR ) based on the Conditional Masked Language Model with Correction ( CMLMC ). The proposed model addresses the issues of indistinguishability of tokens and mismatch between training and inference in NAR. The paper also proposes a correction loss that teaches the model how to correct translation mistakes made in early decoding iterations from the fully masked sentence. Empirically, the proposed model achieves state - of - the - art NAR performance when trained on raw data without distillation.

This paper proposes to use spiking neural dynamics as a natural alternative to dilated temporal convolutions for edge signal processing. The proposed method is inspired by the WaveNet architecture and uses simple neural dynamics, fixed time - constant and a simple feed - forward architecture and hence is particularly well suited for a neuromorphic implementation. The results show that the proposed network beats the state - of - the - art for keyword - spotting on several datasets.

This paper presents a class of algorithms that provide high - confidence behavioral guarantees that hold under demographic shift. Specifically, the authors show that the learned models avoid bias under the demographic shift, unlike existing methods. The paper also provides a constructive proof of the guarantees, an evaluation on real - world data, and an open - source implementation and release of all data.

This paper proposes a neural dual dynamic programming ( SDDP ) approach to solve multi - stage stochastic dual dynamic optimization ( MSSO ) problems. The main idea is to learn a piece - wise linear value function within intrinsic low - dimensional space that can interact with a base SDDP solver to accelerate optimization performance on new instances. The proposed Neural Stochastic Dual Dynamic Programming ( NSDDP ) continually self - improves by solving successive problems. An empirical investigation demonstrates that the proposed approach can significantly reduce problem solving cost without sacrificing solution quality.

This paper proposes a new protocol for next - token prediction for fine - tuning a language model on a private corpus after pre - training on a public corpus. The proposed method is based on a relaxation of group differentially private prediction ( GDP ), which allows it to prevent the leakage of information that is unique to any individual user in the private corpus via a relaxed of the group - differentially - private prediction. The paper also shows that the proposed method can thwart existing data - extraction attacks while maintaining the utility of the language model.

This paper proposes an unsupervised method to detect out - of - distribution ( OOD ) samples using a k - N density estimate with respect to a classification model ’s intermediate activations on indistribution samples. The authors leverage a recent insight about label smoothing, which they call the Label Smoothed Embedding Hypothesis, and show that one of the implications is that the k -NN density estimator performs better as an OOD detection method both theoretically and empirically when the model is trained with label smoothed. The proposed method outperforms many OOD baselines.

This paper proposes a new method for training non - adversarial generative models based on diffusion - based stochastic differential equations ( DDEs ). The proposed method is based on a new formulation of the denoising score matching objective and thus encodes information needed for denoizing. The paper also proposes to learn an infinite - dimensional latent code which achieves improvements of state - of - the - art models on semi - supervised image classification.

This paper proposes a method for goal - conditioned reinforcement learning that learns to reach distant goal - reaching tasks by using planning at training time to automatically generate a curriculum of intermediate states. The algorithm, C - Planning ( C - planning ), is based on expectation maximization and graph search. The method is evaluated on 2D navigation tasks and complex 18D robotic manipulation tasks and shows that it is more sample efficient than prior methods.

This paper extends mixup to k - mixup by perturbing k - batches of training data in the direction of other randomly - chosen instances in the training set using displacement interpolation, i.e. interpolation under the Wasserstein metric. The authors demonstrate theoretically and in simulations that k-mixup preserves cluster and manifold structures, and extend theory studying the efficacy of standard mixup. The empirical results show that training with k - Mixup further improves generalization and robustness across several network architectures and benchmark datasets of differing modalities.

This paper proposes a kernelized classification layer for deep networks to tackle the nonlinear classification problem. The classification layer optimizes over all possible radial kernel functions on the space of embeddings to learn an optimal nonlinear classifier. The paper empirically shows the usefulness of this layer in learning more model - efficient classifiers in a number of computer vision and natural language processing tasks.

This paper theoretically analyzes the sources of bias in node representations obtained via Graph Neural Networks ( GNNs ). Based on the analysis, the authors develop novel fairness - aware graph data augmentations that can reduce potential bias in learning node representations. Extensive experiments on node classification and link prediction are carried out over real networks in the context of graph contrastive learning.

This paper considers the problem of estimating treatment effects from observational data in the presence of unmeasured confounders. The authors propose a Confounder Balanced IV Regression ( CB - IV ) algorithm to jointly remove the bias from the unme measured confounder with IV regression and achieve better bias - variance trade - off in imbalanced treatment distributions. Extensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm on both synthetic and real - world datasets.

This paper studies the performance of model - agnostic meta - learning ( MAML ) in a linear regression setting with a mixture of easy and hard tasks, where hardness is related to the rate that gradient descent converges on the task. The authors prove that in order for MAMl to achieve substantial gain over standard non - adaptive learning ( NAL ), there must be some discrepancy in task hardness among the tasks, and the optimal solutions of the hard tasks must be closely packed with the center far from the center of the easy tasks optimal solutions. They also give numerical results suggesting that these insights apply to two - layer neural networks.

This paper proposes a new method for sparse source separation ( BSS ) based on unrolling. The method leverages data - driven knowledge stemming from realistic simulations or ground - truth data by learning both hyperparameters and variables. The proposed method is able to deal with variable mixing matrices ( a.k.a. variable mixing dictionaries ), which enables to perform semi - blind source separation, which is key to increase the generalization of the learnt model in real - world applications.

This paper studies the scaling properties of transformers in the context of autoregressive language modelling. The authors propose a Legendre Memory Unit - based model that exhibits an O(n ) and O ( n lnn ) dependency for memory and computation respectively. They show that for the same amount of training their model improves the loss over transformers about as much as transformers improve over LSTMs. They also show that adding global self - attention complements our architecture and the augmented model improves performance even further.

This paper proposes a two - stage GAN based on a set of space keypoints that control the position and style of the generated objects and their parts. The keypoint embeddings are learned end - to - end by a GAN network that is trained on the classical GAN objective with internal conditioning on the keypoints. The paper also proposes a new method for unsupervised keypoint detection that contests established autoencoder methods.

This paper studies the phenomenon of representation shrinkage and gradient explosion in deep neural networks with layer normalization using the mean field formalism. The authors show that increasing the depth leads to gradient explosion or representation shrinking. The appearance of at least one of these problems is not restricted to a specific initialization scheme or a choice of activation function, but rather is an inherent property of the fully - connected architecture itself. They also show that popular normalization techniques fail to mitigate these problems.

This paper proposes a line search method for finding optimal step sizes for stochastic gradient descent automatically. The authors claim that the full - batch loss behaves locally parabolically in the direction of the noisy update step directions and the trend of the optimal update step size changes slowly. Based on these findings, the authors propose a line - search method that approximates the full batch loss with a parabola estimated over several mini - batches. Learning rates are derived from such parabolas during training.

This paper proposes a new loss function for Noise - Contrastive Estimation ( NCE ) that replaces the log loss in NCE with an exponential loss. The authors show that the resulting condition number is polynomial in the dimension and the parameter distance between P and Q when the target and noise distributions belong to an exponential family. The proposed method is tested on synthetic and MNIST datasets and is shown to improve performance.

This paper studies the convergence of distributed SGD with Byzantine and Byzantine workers. The authors show that under certain conditions, the convergence guarantee of the proposed method is only $ \epsilon$-approximated under Byzantine faults. To prove this result, the authors re - tune the learning algorithm by carefully re - tuning the parameters of the parameter - server architecture.

This paper considers the problem of code editing in computer source code editing with few exemplars. The authors propose a novel deep learning approach to solve this code editing problem automatically. The approach combines edit representations extracted from support exemplars and compositionally generalizes them to the query code snippet editing via multi - extend similarities ensemble. The proposed method is evaluated on C# and Python datasets, and show up to 8.6 % absolute accuracy improvements compared to non - non - composition baselines.

This paper proposes a novel approach for incorporating high - level structure in the form of relational constraints between different subcomponents of an example ( e.g., lines of a poem or measures of music ). The authors propose a program synthesis algorithm that infers the relational constraints present in the training data, and then learn a generative model based on the resulting constraint data. The experiments show that the proposed approach significantly improves over state - of - the - art approaches.

This paper studies the problem of set - to - hypergraph prediction, where the goal is to infer the set of relations for a given set of entities. The paper addresses two common scaling problems encountered in set to hypergraph tasks : the exponentially growing number of hyperedges and the run - time complexity, both leading to higher memory requirements. The authors propose to predict and supervise the positive edges only, which changes the asymptotic memory scaling from exponential to linear. They also introduce a training method that encourages iterative refinement of the predicted hypergraph.

This paper proposes a post - processing method to mitigate bias of state - of - the - art models. It consists in learning a shallow neural network, called the Ethical Module, which transforms the deep embeddings of a pre - trained model to give more representation power to the discriminated subgroups. Its training is supervised by the von Mises - Fisher loss, whose hyperparameters allow to control the space allocated to each subgroup in the latent space. The resulting methodology is more stable and faster than most current methods of bias mitigation.

This paper proposes a new method for class - incremental learning ( CIL ) based on the use of placebos from a free image stream. Specifically, the authors propose to compute the KD loss using the placebo data from a Google image stream, which is both simple and surprisingly effective even when there is no class overlap between the placebos and the old data. When the image stream is available, they use an evaluation function to quickly judge the quality of candidate images ( good or bad placebos ) and train a reinforcement learning algorithm. The proposed method does not require any additional supervision or memory budget and can significantly improve a number of top - performing CIL methods, in particular on higher - resolution benchmarks, with a lower memory budget for old class exemplars.

This paper proposes a path auxiliary algorithm for inference and learning of discrete energy - based models ( EBM ). The main idea is to use a composition of local moves to efficiently explore large neighborhoods. The authors also give a fast version of their algorithm that only queries the evaluation of energy function twice for each proposal via linearization of the energy function. Empirically, the proposed method outperforms other generic samplers on various discrete models for sampling, inference, and learning. The method can also be used to train deep EBMs for high dimensional discrete data.

This paper proposes a novel method for discovering spatiotemporal boundary discovery in video data. The method is based on a neural probabilistic inference system that organizes latent representations of video features in a temporal hierarchy, based on their rates of change, thus modeling continuous data as a hierarchical renewal process. The proposed method is able to dynamically adjust its internal state following changes in the observed features, promoting an optimal organisation of representations across the levels of the model ’s latent hierarchy.

This paper proposes a method for image retrieval based on unifying global and attention - based local feature matching. The proposed method is an end - to - end and single - stage pipeline, which can be trained end to end. It achieves state - of - the - art performance on two typical datasets with less memory and faster extraction speed compared with other popular methods.

This paper proposes a new method for multi - task learning. The main idea is to jointly homogenize gradient magnitudes and directions across tasks, while ensuring training convergence. The proposed method is evaluated on the NYUv2 dataset, where it outperforms competing methods in complex multi - label classification in CelebA and computer vision tasks.

This paper proposes a model fusion framework for fusing heterogeneous neural networks, namely, unequal width and unequal depth neural networks. The proposed method is based on the cross - layer alignment problem, which is an assignment problem using layer representation and layer similarity, then propose a dynamic programming - based algorithm to solve it. The experiments demonstrate the efficiency of the proposed method on three different setups.

This paper studies the implicit regularization effect of SGD in deep RL in the offline deep RL setting. Theoretical analysis shows that the derived regularizer favors degenerate solutions with excessive “aliasing ”, in stark contrast to the supervised learning case. To address this issue, the authors propose a simple and effective explicit regularizer, DR3, that counteracts the undesirable effects of this implicit regularizer. Empirically, using DR3 in conjunction with existing offline RL methods provides about 60 % performance improvement on the harder D4RL tasks, and 160 % and 25 % stability gains for REM and CQL respectively, on offline RL tasks in 17 Atari 2600 games.

This paper proposes a novel method for exploration in deep reinforcement learning ( RL ). The main idea is to use a probabilistic hypermodel ( meta model ) to generate approximate posterior samples regarding the parameter of the Q - value function. The proposed method is evaluated on the Atari suite with 20 M frames and outperforms DQN with 200 M frames in terms of the maximum human - normalized score on SuperMarioBros.

This paper proposes to learn causal representation from observational data by regularizing the learning procedure with mutual information measures according to a hypothetical causal graph. The optimization involves a counterfactual loss, based on which the authors deduce a theoretical guarantee that the causality - inspired learning is with reduced sample complexity and better generalization ability. Extensive experiments show that the models trained on causal representations learned by the proposed approach is robust under adversarial attacks and distribution shift.

This paper proposes ProgFed, a progressive training framework for efficient and effective federated learning. It inherently reduces computation and two - way communication costs while maintaining the strong performance of the final models. Theoretical results show that the proposed method converges at the same asymptotic rate as standard training on full models. Extensive experiments on various datasets ( CIFAR-10/100, EMNIST and BraTS ) and architectures ( VGG-16/19, ResNet-18/152, ConvNets, 3D - Unet ) show that with the same number of epochs, the proposed framework can save around 25 % computation cost, up to 32 % two - ways communication costs in federated classification, and up to 63 % in Federated segmentation.

This paper studies the generalization of adversarial training through the lens of the adversarial Rademacher complexity. The authors propose a method to overcome the difficulty of the classical analysis for standard training. They also provide upper bounds of the robustness of deep neural networks to adversarial attacks. They show that the large weight norms of an adversarially trained model are one of the reasons why it is difficult to generalize well in adversarial settings.

This paper introduces a kernel - based differential entropy estimator ( KNIFE ) for differential entropy and mutual information ( MI ) estimation. The proposed estimator is differentiable, parameterized, differentiable and can be applied to conditional ( discrete or continuous ) differential entropy as well as mutual information estimators. Experiments on synthetic data and real - world tasks demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new soft - greedy operator, called resmax, that takes actions proportionally to their suboptimality gap : the residual to the estimated maximal value. It is simple to use and ensures coverage of the state - space like softmax, but focuses exploration more on potentially promising actions. It does not concentrate probability as quickly as softmax and so better avoids overemphasizing sub -optimal actions that appear high - valued during learning. The paper also proves that it is a non - expansion for any fixed exploration hyperparameter.

This paper introduces a new concept called “ learnability lock ” for controlling the model ’s learnability on a specific dataset with a special key. In particular, the authors propose adversarial invertible transformation, that can be viewed as a mapping from image to image, to slightly modify data samples so that they become “ unlearnable ” by machine learning models with negligible loss of visual features. The proposed method can be easily restored with a simple inverse transformation while remaining difficult to be detected or reverse - engineered.

This paper proposes a general approach for handling missing features in graph machine learning applications that is based on minimization of the Dirichlet energy and leads to a diffusion - type differential equation on the graph. The discretization of this equation produces a simple, fast and scalable algorithm which is called Feature Propagation. The proposed approach outperforms previous methods on seven common node - classification benchmarks and can withstand surprisingly high rates of missing features when 99 % of the features are missing.

This paper studies the problem of active learning with limited labeled data by selecting a core subset of an unlabeled data pool to label. The authors propose a Generalized Bender Decomposition ( GBC ) algorithm to select a core set that minimizes the discrete Wasserstein distance from the unlabeling pool. The proposed method is evaluated on image classification and domain adaptation tasks where less than 1 % of the data set is labeled.

This paper proposes a method for de - novo genome assembly using graph neural networks. Specifically, a graph convolutional network is trained on a dataset generated from human genomic data to reconstruct the genome by finding a path through the assembly graph. The authors show that their model can compute scores from the lengths of the overlaps between the sequences and the graph topology and outperforms greedy search algorithms in the greedy search over the overlap lengths only.

This paper proposes to use experience replay ( ER ) to improve continual learning representations by integrating ER also into meta - training. The idea is to store the samples ’ representations, instead of the samples themselves, into the replay buffer. This ensures the batch nature of ER does not conflict with the online - aware nature of OML. Experimental results on a number of real - world meta - continual learning benchmark data sets demonstrate the proposed method outperforms the state - of - the - art.

This paper proposes a new method for multi - agent joint Q - learning based on centralized training with decentralized execution ( CTE ). The authors propose a criterion to measure an assignment function so that they can find better assignments by explicitly optimizing this criterion. Theoretically, the authors also give a gradient ascent solution for this problem. Empirically, they instantiate the core idea with deep neural networks and propose Explicit Credit Assignment Joint Q - Learning ( ECAQ ). Extensive experiments justify the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper studies the problem of attacking transductive learning - based defense mechanisms.
