The authors propose a new attack framework called Greedy Model Space Attack ( GMSA ) that can be used as a new baseline for evaluating transductively learning based defenses. They show that even weak instantiations of GMSA can break existing defenses. On the positive side, they show that adversarially retraining the model using fresh randomness at the test time gives a significant increase in robustness against attacks we consider.

This paper studies the problem of per - example batch normalization. In particular, the authors propose a method to approximate the gradient from the limiting case where the entire dataset is normalized jointly and explore other ways of approximating the gradient. The proposed method is based on the idea of moving first and second moments, and an aggregation step that joins the information from multiple examples similar to the way that the gradients with respect to the model parameters are commonly averaged over the minibatch in SGD.

This paper proposes a method to reduce the number of trainable parameters for fine - tuning a pre - trained Transformer model. The main idea is to inject trainable rank decomposition matrices into each layer of the Transformer architecture, which can be used for downstream tasks. Experiments show that the proposed method is able to improve the performance of the model compared to finetuning a GPT-3 175B model.

This paper proposes a generalization of linear - chain conditional random field ( CRF ) that can enforce a broad class of constraints, including non - local ones, by specifying the space of possible output structures as a regular language. The resulting regular - constrained CRF ( RegCCRF ) has the same formal properties as a standard CRF, but assigns zero probability to all label sequences not in L. The domain knowledge specifying these constraints is defined via regular expressions, a straightforward, well understood formalism. The paper shows that the method is distinct from approaches that enforce constraints at decoding time, and that it better approximates the true data distribution.

This paper proposes two novel and efficient neural models for camera - based physiological measurement called EfficientPhys that remove the need for face detection, segmentation, normalization, color space transformation or any other preprocessing steps. Using an input of raw video frames, the proposed models achieve state - of - the - art accuracy on three public datasets. The experiments show that this is the case whether using a transformer or convolutional backbone.

This paper proposes Hardware - aware Latency Pruning ( HALP ), a method for network pruning. The proposed method is based on a global resource allocation problem, aiming at maximizing the accuracy while constraining the latency under a predefined budget. The method leverages latency lookup table to track the latency reduction potential and global saliency score to gauge the accuracy drop. This makes the problem solvable via an augmented knapsack solver.

This paper proposes a molecular graph generation method via energy - based models ( EBMs ) to perform permutation invariant and multi - objective molecule generation. The proposed method learns the energy function by contrastive divergence and generate samples by Langevin dynamics. To generate molecules with a specific desirable property, the authors propose a simple yet effective learning strategy, which pushes down energies with flexible degrees according to the properties of corresponding molecules. The experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new method for program synthesis based on bottom - up search. The key idea is to train a neural model to learn a hands - on search policy instead of relying on a combinatorial search algorithm. The proposed method is evaluated in two different domains, string manipulation and logic programming. The results show that the proposed method outperforms state - of - the - art methods on the two domains.

This paper proposes a new regularization method for deep reinforcement learning based on the squared Bellman error. The proposed method is based on implicit regularization of the target network. The regularization is explicit and enables the authors to use up - to - date parameters as well as control the regularization. This leads to a faster yet more stable training method in terms of sample efficiency and performance across a range of Atari environments.

This paper proposes a general solution to inject structural properties of graphs into a message - passing aggregation scheme of Graph Neural Networks ( GNNs ). The authors develop a new hierarchy of local isomorphism on neighborhood subgraphs and theoretically characterize how message - pass - passing GNN can be designed to be more expressive than the Weisfeiler Lehman test. To elaborate this characterization, the authors propose a novel neural model, called GraphSNN, and prove that this model is strictly more expressive in distinguishing graph structures. The experimental results verify the strength of the proposed model on different graph learning tasks.

This paper proposes a novel prediction interval ( PIs ) quantification method for uncertainty quantification. The proposed method calculates PIs from linear combinations of three NNs, each of which is independently trained using the standard mean squared error loss. The coefficients of the linear combinations are computed using root - finding algorithms to ensure tight PIs for a series of confidence levels without retraining NNs and it completely avoids the crossing issue.

This paper proposes a fully online meta - learning algorithm that does not require any ground truth knowledge of task boundaries and does not reset the online parameters back to the meta - parameters between tasks. The proposed method is evaluated on Rainbow - MNIST and CIFAR100 datasets and shows that it is able to learn new tasks faster than the state - of - the - art online learning methods.

This paper proposes a method for molecular optimization ( MOMO ). The main idea is to use a learned knowledge network to convert discrete chemical structures to locally differentiable ones by back - propagating the derivatives from the target properties through a graph neural network ( GNN ). Empirical results show that the proposed method is effective and sample efficient.

This paper proposes a knowledge - augmented approach to predict the response of a patient to a target lab test result. The authors model drug - lab interactions as graphs and use graph attention networks to model the positive and negative effects of drugs and diagnosis on the target lab result. They also take into consideration patients ’ past lab responses to personalize the prediction. Experiments on real - world datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed solution in reducing prediction errors by a significant margin.

This paper studies the problem of single domain generalization ( SDG ) in the setting where the source and target domains do not share the same label space. The authors propose a novel approach named CrossMatch to address the OS - SDG problem by generating auxiliary samples that are potentially out of the source label space during training. The auxiliary samples may not belong to the actual unknown classes in the target domains. However, they could still assist in identifying whether a sample belongs to known classes or not. In particular, they adopt a multi - binary classifier that consists of multiple one - vs - all binary classifiers to generate auxiliary samples for unknown classes. They also adopt a consistency regularization to improve the capability of model on unknown class identification by propagating unknown class information.

This paper proposes two extensions of trust - region methods based on Kullback - Leibler divergence for policy optimization in reinforcement learning. The main idea is to directly optimize the policy distribution and derive their close - form policy updates based on the Lagrangian duality. Theoretically, they show that WPO guarantees a monotonic performance improvement and SPO provably converges to WPO as the entropic regularizer diminishes. Experiments across tabular domains and robotic locomotion tasks further demonstrate the performance improvement of both approaches.

This paper proposes a forget - and - re - learn paradigm for shaping the learning trajectories of artificial neural networks. The forgetting step selectively removes undesirable information from the model, and the relearning step reinforces features that are consistently useful under different conditions. The proposed framework unifies many existing iterative training algorithms in the image classification and language emergence literature, and allows to understand the success of these algorithms in terms of the disproportionate forgetting of undesirable information. The authors leverage this understanding to improve upon existing algorithms by designing more targeted forgetting operations.

This paper studies the offline - online batch RL setting, where the agent has access to a batch of data to train on but is also allowed to learn during the evaluation phase in an online manner. This is an extension to batch RL, allowing the agent to adapt to new situations without having to precommit to a policy. The experiments show that standard RL agents trained in an offline - offline manner can outperform agents trained only offline or online, sometimes by a large margin.

This paper studies the problem of domain generalization ( DG ) via learning to reduce domain shift with an episodic training procedure. In particular, the authors learn to optimize Y - discrepancy between the unseen target domain and source domains only using source - domain samples. Theoretically, they give a PAC - style generalization bound for discrepancyoptimal meta - learning and further make comparisons with other DG bounds including ERM and domain - invariant learning. The theoretical results also shed light on a bilevel optimization algorithm for DG. Empirically, the algorithm achieves state - of - the - art results on two DG benchmarks.

This paper studies the problem of best - first search in Sokoban planning with deep neural networks ( DNNs ) in the NP - complete PSPACE setting. In particular, the authors study the existence of left heavy tails and propose an abstract tree model that can empirically explain the appearance of these tails. The experiments show the critical role of the policy network as a heuristic guiding the search, which can lead to left heavy tail with polynomial scaling by avoiding exploring exponentially sized sub - trees.

This paper presents a method for meta - imitation learning by translating human video demonstrations into robot demonstrations and train the meta - policy with adaptive loss based on the quality of the translated data. The approach relies only on human videos and does not require robot demonstration, which facilitates data collection and is more in line with human imitation behavior. The method achieves comparable performance to the baselines in one - shot new task learning on vision - based tasks through watching a single video demonstration.

This paper studies the problem of training over - parameterized deep networks using gradient - based optimizers ( GBOs ). In particular, it studies the effect of large batch size on the generalization performance. The authors argue that large batch sizes are useful for speeding up the training process by leveraging parallel GPUs. The noise diminishes with increasing batch sizes, which is why small batch sizes yield better generalization.

This paper proposes a method for learning partial equivariant convolutional neural networks ( G - CNNs ). The key idea is to learn to respect the chosen symmetries of the data and to restrict the equivariance of the network when necessary. The method is evaluated on 6 / 9 MNIST and natural image classification tasks. The results show that the proposed method outperforms the state - of - the - art methods when necessary and outperforms them otherwise.

This paper proposes to replace the datapoint - wise MCMC iterations with updates of an inference model that maps observations into latent variables. The proposed method is based on the Langevin dynamics and is scalable to large - scale datasets. The authors prove that the target posterior of the proposed method has stationary distribution under some assumptions and can be extended to an unconditional distribution such as an energy - based model.

This paper studies the problem of hypergraph reasoning, i.e., predicting the relationship between several entities based on the input facts. The authors observe that in logical reasoning, logical rules usually apply locally ( e.g., only three people are involved in a grandparent rule ) and sparsely (e.g., the grandparent relationship is sparse across all pairs of people in the world ). Inspired by these observations, the authors propose a structured neural network called SpaLoc that leverages the sparsity in hypergraph neural networks to leverage the grounding of relationships such as parent and grandparent as sparse tensors and uses neural networks and finite - domain quantification operations to infer new facts. To remedy the information loss in sampled sub - graphs, they propose a novel sampling and label calibration paradigm based on an information - theoretic measure information sufficiency.

This paper proposes a new family of top - k cross - entropy classification losses based on the assumption that k is a positive integer such as 1 or 5. The main idea is to draw k from a probability distribution for training and relax the assumption of a fixed k. The authors show that relaxing k does not only produce better top - 5 accuracies but also makes models more robust, which leads to top - 1 accuracy improvements.

This paper proposes a fast and reliable method for solving large - scale optimal transport ( OT ) problems at an unprecedented combination of speed and accuracy. The method is based on the Douglas - Rachford splitting technique and tackles the original OT problem directly instead of solving an approximate regularized problem, as many state - of - the - art techniques do. The algorithm has the same cost per iteration as the popular Sinkhorn method, and each iteration can be executed efficiently, in parallel. The proposed method enjoys an iteration complexity O(1/2 ) compared to the best - known O ( 1/3 ) of the S sinkhorn method. The authors also establish a linear convergence rate for the formulation of the OT problem.

This paper proposes a framework for disentangling performance gaps in generalization studies in federated learning by separating performance gaps from unseen client data ( out - of - sample gap ) from performance gap from unseen clients distributions ( participation gap ). The framework is based on the idea of dataset synthesis strategy, and the authors propose a semantic synthesis strategy that enables realistic simulation without naturally - partitioned data. The authors conduct a systematic study of generalization in FL across six tasks. They observe and explain differences in behavior across natural and synthetic federated datasets. They use their results to inform a series of recommendations for future works studying generalisation in FL.

This paper studies the few - shot setting of prompt - based language models ( PLMs ). The authors propose a simple multi - null prompting ( without manually / automatically created prompts ) strategy that yields very promising results on a few widely - used datasets. They also observe some limitations of PLMs under the zero - shot settings, particularly for the language understanding tasks.

This paper proposes a method to improve the alignment and interpretability of attention in image recognition tasks. The key idea is to add a sharpener module to the attention mechanism that aims to align the aligned parts of the encoded image with the target output. Experiments on synthetic handwritten and real - world scene text recognition datasets show that the proposed method outperforms the state - of - the - art.

This paper proposes a novel approach to solve combinatorial optimization problems with a fixed number of vehicles. The proposed approach is based on a supervised deep learning framework that constructs a complete tour plan from scratch while respecting an apriori given number of available vehicles. Experiments show that the proposed approach outperforms baselines in terms of competitive results when considering the practical aspect of vehicle costs.

This paper proposes a method to improve link prediction by causal inference by learning to answer counterfactual questions about link existence. The proposed method is based on learning the causal relationship between global graph structure and the existence of link between a pair of nodes. The method is evaluated on several benchmark datasets and shows state - of - the - art performance.

This paper proposes a two - stage unsupervised feature selection method that incorporates the second - order covariance matrix with the first - order data matrix for feature selection. In the first stage, the authors learn a sparse attention matrix that can represent second - orders relations between features and in the second stage, they build a relational graph based on the learned attention matrix and perform graph segmentation. Experimental results on 12 public datasets show that SOFT outperforms classical and recent state - of - the - art methods.

This paper proposes a new approach for multi - modal multimodal variational autoencoders ( VAEs ) that combines information between modalities implicitly through mutual supervision. This formulation naturally allows learning from partially - observed data where some modalities can be entirely missing — something that most existing approaches either cannot handle, or do so to a limited extent. The proposed approach outperforms baselines on standard metrics across both partial and complete observation schemes on the MNIST - SVHN ( image - image ) and CUB ( image–text ) datasets.

This paper proposes a method for combining intrinsic and extrinsic reward signals in reinforcement learning. The proposed method is called Deep Explore Options. The method is based on the idea of using a transition selection algorithm based on interest of multiple agents in order to isolate exploitative or exploratory behaviors. Experiments show that the proposed method outperforms baselines in 4 of the 6 simulated Atari environments.

This paper proposes a new method for learning Hamiltonian dynamical systems from data. The proposed method splits the training data into stiff and non - stiff portions based on a stiffness - aware index. This classification along with a resampling technique allows to apply different time integration strategies such as step size adaptation to better capture the dynamical characteristics of the Hamiltonian vector fields. The method is evaluated on complex physical systems including a three - body problem and billiard model.

This paper studies the problem of multi - step computations in the few - shot regime of pre - trained language models. In particular, the authors train Transformers to emit intermediate computation steps into a “ scratchpad ” and then train them to emit full program traces line - by - line annotated with local variables to improve their ability to predict the result of executing a given computer program on a particular input.

This paper proposes a novel method to generate adversarial perturbations that are interpretable, universal to any source image, and physically - realizable. The proposed method is based on deep image generators and a novel optimization objective. The authors show that the proposed method can generate targeted feature - level adversarial attacks at the ImageNet scale that are simultaneously interpretable and universal. They also use these adversaries to guide the design of copy / paste attacks in which one natural image is pasted into another to induce an unrelated misclassification.

This paper proposes a new method for solving stochastic annealing problems. The main idea is to use a neural network to learn the neighbor proposal distribution and temperature schedule. The proposed method outperforms hand - selected parameters on a number of problems and scales well with a fixed computational budget.

This paper studies the non - stationarity problem in cooperative multi - agent reinforcement learning ( MARL ). The authors propose a novel notion of stationarity, which is bounded by the joint policy divergence of consecutive joint policies. They then propose a trust - region decomposition network ( TRD - Net ) based on message passing to estimate the joint policies ’ divergence more accurately. The proposed method can bring noticeable and stable performance improvement compared with baselines in cooperative tasks of different complexity.

This paper proposes a self - supervised representation learning framework for audio - visual speech, which masks multi - stream video input and predicts automatically discovered and iteratively refined multimodal hidden units. On the largest public lip - reading benchmark LRS3 (433 hours ), AV - HuBERT achieves 32.5 % WER with only 30 hours of labeled data, outperforming the former state - of - the - art approach ( 33.6%) trained with a thousand times more transcribed video data ( 31K hours ). The lip -reading WER is further reduced to 26.9 % when using all the labeled data from LRS4 and combined with self - training.

This paper proposes a novel algorithm for combinatorial optimisation on graphs. The main idea is to restrict the GNN to a single pre - processing step, before entering a fast - acting exploratory phase directed by a recurrent unit. The experimental results show that the proposed method achieves a new SOTA for RL algorithms on the Maximum Cut problem, while also providing orders of magnitude improvement in speed and scalability.

This paper proposes a new method for training VAEs with discrete latent variables. The proposed method is based on direct discrete optimization, which is different from standard VAE training methods such as sampling approximation, reparameterization trick and amortization. The main idea is to use truncated posteriors in conjunction with evolutionary algorithms ( using a recently suggested approach ). The experimental results show the effectiveness of the proposed method in zero - shot learning and denoising.

This paper proposes an unsupervised method based on counterfactual measures of blame to identify effects on the environment controlled by the agent. The proposed method is evaluated in a wide range of environments showing that it can accurately identify controlled effects. The authors also demonstrate its capabilities as intrinsic motivator by integrating it in the state - of - the - art exploration method, achieving substantially better performance than action - prediction models.

This paper proposes a structure - regularized pruning ( SRP ) method to train efficient image super - resolution ( SR ) networks. The proposed method imposes regularization on the pruned structure to make sure the locations of pruned filters are aligned across different layers. The authors conduct extensive comparisons with both lightweight and larger image SR networks and achieve superior performance gains over recent methods.

This paper proposes a framework for few - shot learning that tackles large domain shift between base and novel categories. The framework trains a feature extracting backbone with the contrastive loss on the base category data and uses a masking module to select relevant features that are more suited to target domain classification. Finally, a classifier is fine - tuned along with the backbone such that the backbone produces features similar to the relevant ones. The proposed method is evaluated on a recently introduced cross - domain few - shots learning benchmark.

This paper studies the generalization ability of neural networks trained by gradient descent ( GDP ) and finite width neural networks ( FNN ) trained by Bayesian inference ( BN ). The main result is that GDP can improve generalization by selecting networks with a large margin. To measure the implicit bias of architecture, new technical tools are developed to both analytically bound and consistently estimate the average test error of the neural network - Gaussian process ( NNGP ) posterior. This error is found to be already better than chance, corroborating the findings of Valle - Pérez et al ( 2019 ).

This paper proposes a new method for cross - lingual transfer based on the manifold mixup ( X - mixup ) method, which adaptively calibrates the representation discrepancy and gives compromised representations for target languages. Experiments on the XTREME benchmark show X - Mixup achieves 1.8 % performance gains on multiple text understanding tasks, compared with strong baselines, and reduces the cross -lingual representation discrepancy significantly.

This paper studies Byzantine robust distributed or federated learning, where a central server wants to train a machine learning model over data distributed across multiple workers. However, a fraction of these workers may deviate from the prescribed algorithm and send arbitrary messages to the server. In this setting, the data across workers are heterogeneous ( non - iid ). The authors propose a simple bucketing scheme that adapts existing robust algorithms to heterogeneous datasets at a negligible computational cost and theoretically and experimentally validate their approach.

This paper studies the relationship between disentanglement and multi - task learning based on hard - parameter sharing. The authors perform a thorough empirical study of the representations obtained by neural networks trained on automatically generated supervised tasks. Using a set of standard metrics, the authors show that disentangled representations appear naturally during the process of multi - tasks neural network training. They verify their hypotheses by training multiple models in single - and multi task settings and investigating the level of disentangling achieved in their latent representations.

This paper proposes a framework for certifying robust policies against adversarial state perturbations in reinforcement learning. The framework is based on the CROP framework, which provides state - level robustness certification and the first certification for cumulative rewards. The authors propose two particular types of robustness criteria : robustness of per - state actions and lower bound of cumulative rewards, and propose a local smoothing algorithm that uses a policy derived from Q - functions smoothed with Gaussian noise over each encountered state to guarantee the robustness. They also propose a global smoothing approach that makes use of adaptive search in order to obtain tight certification bounds for the reward.

This paper proposes a new approach to conformal prediction, which aims to output a precise set of promising prediction candidates that is guaranteed to contain a limited number of incorrect answers. The proposed approach trades coverage for precision by enforcing that the presence of incorrect candidates in the predicted conformal sets is bounded according to a user - specified tolerance. Subject to this constraint, the proposed algorithm optimizes for a generalized notion of set coverage ( i.e., the true positive rate ) that allows for any number of true answers for a given query ( including zero ).

This paper studies the behavior of ReLU networks with standard random initialization. The authors show that the expected length distortion does not grow with depth, and indeed shrinks slightly, when the weights and biases of a ReLU network are multiplied by C. The authors also generalize this result by proving upper bounds for higher moments of the length distortion and for the distortion of higher - dimensional volumes.

This paper proposes a behavioral prior learning algorithm to accelerate policy learning on complex control tasks under safety constraints. The proposed method is based on contrastive training on safe and unsafe data and learns to extract a safety variable from offline data that encodes safety requirements. In the inference stage, SAFER composes a safe and successful policy from the safety skills according to the inferred safety variable and abstract action. The method is evaluated on several complex safety - critical robotic grasping tasks inspired by the game Operation.

This paper proposes a multi - branch restoration model inspired from the Human Visual System ( i.e., Retinal Ganglion Cells ) which can achieve multiple restoration tasks in a general framework. The experiments show that the proposed model has competitive performance results on four datasets, including image dehazing, deraindrop, and deblurring.

This paper proposes a new federated learning setup, Inference - Time PFL ( IT - PFL ), where a model trained on a set of clients needs to be evaluated on novel unlabeled clients at inference time. The proposed approach is based on a hypernetwork module and an encoder module and is evaluated on four benchmark datasets.    The paper shows that the proposed approach generalizes better than current FL and PFL methods, especially when the novel client has a large domain shift.

This paper uses a conditional diffusion based generative model ( RCDM ) to visualize representations learned with self - supervised models to evaluate how much information is retained in the representation of a given input. The authors show that SSL representations are not really invariant to many data augmentation tasks like classifications, and SSL representations appear to retain information on object scale, grayscale vs color, and color palette of the background, much like supervised representation. They also show that supervised representations appear more susceptible to adversarial attacks.

This paper proposes a new sensitivity definition called pure multiplicative sensitivity for frequency moments estimation ( FPM ). The authors prove that FPM sketch is differentially private as is when p is $ p$ ( 0,1)$ and uses only polylogarithmic space, which is exponentially better than existing DP baselines and only worse than the optimal non - private baseline. The evaluation shows that Fp sketch can achieve reasonable accuracy with differential privacy guarantee.

This paper proposes a novel reward - switching policy optimization ( RSPO ) algorithm for discovering diverse strategies in complex RL environments by iteratively finding novel policies that are both locally optimal and sufficiently different from existing ones. To encourage the learning policy to consistently converge towards a previously undiscovered local optimum, the proposed algorithm switches between extrinsic and intrinsic rewards via a trajectory - based novelty measurement during the optimization process. Experiments show that the proposed method is able to discover a wide spectrum of strategies in a variety of domains ranging from single - agent particle - world tasks and MuJoCo continuous control to multi - agent stag - hunt games and StarCraftII challenges.

This paper proposes a new method for fast diffusion model samplers. The main idea is to use gradient descent to optimize the degrees of freedom of the generalized Gaussian Diffusion Models ( GGDM ) sampler by maximizing sample quality scores via gradient descent. The proposed method achieves state - of - the - art FID scores on unconditional image generation across various datasets.

This paper studies the problem of querying large language models ( LMs ) for natural language queries. The authors propose a lightweight model called P - Adapters that sits between the embedding layer and first attention layer of LLMs. They take LLM embeddings as input and output continuous prompts that are used to query the LLM. They also investigate Mixture of Experts ( MoE ) models that learn a set of continuous prompts ( “experts ” ) and select one to query. They require a separate classifier trained on human - annotated data to query natural language prompts to the continuous ones.

This paper proposes a continuous classification of time series ( CCTS ) method to achieve high accuracy classification at every time. The key of the proposed method is to model multiple distributions simultaneously, which is different from the existing one - shot classification. The authors propose a novel Adaptive model training policy ACCTS to overcome two main problems : catastrophic forgetting and overfitting. Experiments on four real - world datasets show that the method can classify more accurately than all baselines at each time.

This paper proposes a method to extend language models with external memory to memorize the internal representations of past inputs. The main idea is to use an approximate kNN lookup into the memory to improve language modeling across various benchmarks and tasks, including generic webtext ( C4 ), math papers ( arXiv ), books ( PG-19 ), code ( GitHub ), and formal theorems ( Isabelle ). The performance steadily improves when we increase the size of memory up to 131k tokens.

This paper proposes a sampling scheme based on Metropolis - Hastings Monte Carlo algorithm to sample from large pretrained MLMs. The samples are proposed from the same masked conditionals used for training the masked language models, and they are accepted or rejected based on their energy values according to the target distribution. The authors validate the effectiveness of the proposed parametrizations by exploring the quality of samples drawn from these energybased models for both open - ended unconditional generation and conditional generation task of machine translation.

This paper proposes a novel reward function for learning a good data augmentation policy for NLP tasks. The authors propose to construct more diverse and challenging samples for providing informative training signals, while avoiding the risk of losing the semantics of original samples ( DND ). They also introduce a sample re - weighting scheme to focus on difficult augmented samples after the original ones are learned confidently for more effective learning from the augmented ones. The proposed method outperforms the recent state - of - the - art augmentation schemes on various text classification tasks and GLUE benchmark.

This paper proposes a method to improve upon FOCAL by incorporating intra - task attention mechanism and inter - task contrastive learning objectives to robustify task representation learning against sparse reward and distribution shift in offline RL. Theoretical analysis and experiments are presented to demonstrate the superior performance and robustness of the proposed method compared to prior algorithms across multiple meta - RL benchmarks.

This paper proposes an inference - time improvement framework for parametric sequential generative modeling methods called belief fine - tuning ( BFT ). BFT leverages approximate dynamic programming to determine the model parameters at each time step. It can improve the accuracy of the belief model at test time because it specializes the capacity of the model to the space of local observations. Furthermore, this specialization occurs after the action or policy has already been decided, BFT does not require the belief models to process it as input. The paper demonstrates the effectiveness of BFT on Hanabi in the cooperative imperfect - information game Hanabi.

This paper proposes a method for speeding up sparse training of overparameterized neural networks. The main idea is to optimize over a continuous superset of sparse matrices with a fixed structure known as products of butterfly matrices. The proposed method uses a simple fixed sparsity pattern based on flat block and low - rank matrices to sparsify most network layers ( e.g. attention, MLP ). Experiments are conducted on ImageNet classification and WikiText-103 language modeling tasks, and show that the proposed method can speed up the training of models without quality drop compared to baselines.

This paper proposes a method for conditional image generation based on score - based probabilistic models. The authors propose to explicitly model the class center in the forward and reverse process of the Markov chain and explore the class clustering phenomenon. They conduct extensive experiments on multiple tasks and achieve competitive results compared with the state - of - the - art methods.

This paper proposes a method for domain generalization ( DG ) based on latent subspaces. The idea is to use label - informative features captured in source domains to learn latent sub - spaces and learn individual hypotheses on those sub - spaces. The proposed method is evaluated on several well - known DG benchmarks and achieves state - of - the - art results.

This paper studies the kernel thinning ( KT ) algorithm of Dwivedi and Mackey ( 2021 ), which compresses a probability distribution more effectively than independent sampling by targeting a reproducing kernel Hilbert space ( RKHS ) and leveraging a less smooth squareroot kernel.   The authors provide four improvements to the original KT algorithm. First, they show that applying the target KT directly to the target Hilbert space yields tighter, dimension - free guarantees for any kernel, any distribution, and any fixed function in the target space. Second, for analytic kernels like Gaussian, inverse multiquadric, and sinc, target KT admits maximum mean discrepancy ( MMD ) guarantees comparable to or better than those of square root KT without making explicit use of a square root kernel. Third, they prove that KT with a fractional power kernel yields better - than -Monte - Carlo guarantees for non - smooth kernels. Fourth, they establish that KT applied to a sum of target and power kernels simultaneously inherits the improved MMD guarantees of power KT and the tighter individual function guarantees of target KT.

This paper presents an open - source benchmark suite for combinatorial optimization problems. The benchmark suite is a unified interface to various state - of - the - art traditional and machine learning - based solvers. The authors also conduct an in - depth analysis of the popular guided tree search algorithm by Li et al. ( 2018 ) on small and large synthetic and real - world graphs. The results show that the graph convolution network used in the tree search does not learn meaningful representation of the solution structure and can in fact be replaced by random values.

This paper proposes Wavelet Compressed Convolution ( WCC ), a novel approach for compression for activation maps compression for 1 - 1 convolutions ( the workhorse of modern CNNs ). WCC achieves compression ratios and computational savings that are equivalent to low bit quantization rates at a relatively minimal loss of accuracy. To this end, the authors use a hardware - friendly Haar - wavelet transform, known for its effectiveness in image compression, and define the convolution on the compressed activation map. Experiments are conducted on two image - to - image tasks : semantic segmentation and depth prediction.

This paper studies the problem of learning correlated and coarse correlated equilibria in extensive - form games. The main contribution of the paper is the development of a fast no - regret learning algorithm for the correlated correlated equilibrium ( EFCE ) in multiplayer general - sum imperfect - information extensive -form games. Specifically, the authors show that when all agents play T repetitions of the game according to the accelerated dynamics, the correlated distribution of play is an O(T(3/4)-approximate ) correlated equilibrium. This significantly improves over the best prior rate of O(1/2 ).

This paper proposes a method to learn discrete action discretization from demonstrations in reinforcement learning. The main idea is to learn a discretized action space by leveraging the priors of demonstrations. The proposed method is evaluated on three downstream tasks : RL with demonstrations, RL with play data, and Imitation Learning. The results show that the proposed method outperforms state - of - the - art continuous control methods on all three tasks.

This paper studies the problem of domain generalization in semantic segmentation. The authors propose a novel adversarial style augmentation ( AdvStyle ) approach, which can dynamically generate hard stylized images during training and thus can effectively prevent the model from overfitting on the source domain. Experiments on two synthetic - to - real datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a novel method for mid - air gesture recognition. The main idea is to use a dynamic vision sensor ( DVS ) to capture high - resolution gesture data at high temporal resolution. The proposed method encodes the event - based gesture data into a latent space representation which is then used to compute the similarity of mid air gesture data. The experimental results show that the proposed method achieves 87 % classification accuracy on the DVSGesture dataset.

This paper proposes a sparse hierarchical table ensemble ( S - HTE ) based on ferns for tabular data inference. The idea is to learn a sparse representation of the table, which is then used as a final predictor to improve the performance of the model. The method is evaluated on classification and regression tasks and is shown to be competitive with baselines.

This paper proposes an offline RL method for learning value functions from state - only experience in discrete Markov decision processes ( MDPs ). The authors first theoretically characterize the applicability of tabular Q - learning in this setting and then propose a method that learns the same value function under any arbitrary refinement of the action space. The proposed method is evaluated on 5 environments ranging from 2D grid world to 3D visual navigation in realistic environments.

This paper proposes a model - parallel training algorithm SWARM for swarms of poorly connected, heterogeneous unreliable devices. The main idea is to train a large Transformer language model with 1.1 B shared parameters ( $ \mathcal{B}$ before sharing ) on a swarm of preemptible T4 GPUs with less than 400 Mb/s network throughput. The paper also proposes compression - aware architecture modifications to further reduce the network usage of the proposed method.

This paper proposes an online transition correction ( OTC ) method for offline multi - agent reinforcement learning ( MARL ). The proposed method is based on the observation that the transition dynamics in offline training do not accord with the transitions in online execution, which leads to uncoordinated and suboptimal policies. To address this issue, the authors propose two types of distance measures to measure the similarity between transitions, and propose an adaptive rank - based prioritization to sample transitions according to the transition similarity. The experimental results show that the proposed method outperforms baselines in a variety of tasks.

This paper proposes a new method for quantizing the forward and backward phase of neural network training. The proposed method is based on the logarithmic unbiased quantization ( LUQ ) method and achieves state - of - the - art results in 4 - bit training. In addition to the proposed method, the authors also propose a method for avoiding multiplications during two - thirds of the training process, thus reducing by 5x the area used by the multiplier.

This paper studies the problem of learning polythetic classifications in the presence of task - irrelevant features in a meta - learning setting. The authors show that threshold meta - learners require an embedding dimension that is exponential in the number the task - relevant features to emulate these functions. In contrast, attentional classifiers, such as Matching Networks, are able to solve these problems with linear embedding dimensions. To address this challenge, the authors propose a self - attention feature - selection mechanism that adaptively dilutes non - discriminative features. Experiments on synthetic and real - world few - shot learning tasks demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes an environment and training methodology to study the emergence of emergent language between agents using a continuous communication channel trained through reinforcement learning. The authors propose a simple messaging environment where a " speaker " needs to convey a concept to a " listener ". The speaker is equipped with a vocoder that maps symbols to a continuous waveform, and the listener needs to map the continuous signal to the concept. Using deep Q - learning, the authors show that basic compositionality emerges in the learned language representations. They also show that noise is essential in the communication channel when conveying unseen concept combinations.

This paper proposes a novel backdoor attack against pre - trained NLP models. The key idea is to inject a backdoor to the model before it is released to the public for training downstream models. Then, any downstream models transferred from the released model will inherit the backdoor. The proposed method is tested on 10 different downstream tasks and achieves performance drop of up to 100 %.

This paper proposes an incremental skill discovery method that learns skills one after another in an incremental fashion. The proposed method is evaluated in both evolving and static environments and outperforms state - of - the - art skill discovery methods on both skill quality and the ability to solve downstream tasks. Experiments on continuous control tasks show that the proposed method outperforms the state of the art methods on skill quality as well as sample and computational efficiency.

This paper proposes a novel log - polar space convolution ( LPSC ) layer, where the convolution kernel is elliptical and adaptively divides its local receptive field into different regions according to the relative directions and logarithmic distances. Experiments on different tasks and datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new information bottleneck based on the PAC - Bayes generalization bound for neural networks ( NNs ). The bottleneck is built on the trade - off between accuracy and information complexity of NNs, namely PIB. The paper also proposes a Bayesian inference algorithm based on stochastic gradient Langevin dynamics ( SGLD ) for sampling from the optimal weight posterior specified by PIB, and shows that the new information measure covers the wide ground of NN's behavior.

This paper studies the linear separability property of data poisoning attacks. It shows that the perturbations of advanced attacks are almost linear separable when assigned with the target labels of the corresponding samples. This is an important property for various perturbation that were not unveiled before. The paper also shows that linear separibility is indeed the workhorse for recent attacks.

This paper proposes a new algorithm for offline policy optimization based on importance sampling. The key idea is to constrain the potential action set to the set of observed actions with similar states to prevent improper avoidance to lower - reward initial states. The proposed algorithm is evaluated on a medical simulator and a real - world medical dataset. It outperforms the state - of - the - art algorithms.

This paper presents a method for continual learning of how language is grounded in vision. Given a pre - trained multimodal embedding model, where language and images are projected in the same semantic space ( CLIP by OpenAI ), CoLLIE learns a transformation function that adjusts the language embeddings when needed to accommodate new language use. Unlike traditional few - shot learning, the model does not just learn new classes and labels, but can also generalize to similar language use in the future. The model is evaluated on two different tasks of continual learning and shows that it can efficiently learn and generalize from only a few examples.

This paper proposes a novel method for novel object captioning ( NOC ). The proposed method is based on the VLAF2 framework, which is a combination of several existing visual / language models. The main idea is to learn a model that is able to describe novel objects with fluent and natural language expression. The method is evaluated on the benchmark nocaps dataset and achieves state - of - the - art results in terms of fluency, fidelity, and fluency.

This paper studies the phenomenon of neural collapse, a clustering property of overparameterized classification networks, where the features learned by over - parameterized networks show an interesting clustering. The authors show that neural collapse generalizes to new samples from the training classes, and – more importantly – to new classes as well, allowing foundation models to provide feature maps that work well in transfer learning and, specifically, in the few - shot setting.

This paper proposes a deep point cloud reconstruction method that combines densification, denoising, and complete inaccurate reconstruction tasks. The method consists of two stages : 1 ) a sparse stacked - hourglass network for densification and 2 ) a refinement via transformers converting the discrete voxels into 3D points. Extensive experiments demonstrate that the proposed method achieves state - of - the - art performance.

This paper proposes a new method for distributed GCN training. The main idea is to use inter - partition communication with intra - partition computation to hide the communication overhead of communicating node features and feature gradients among partitions for every GCN layer in each training iteration. The convergence rate of the proposed method is shown to be close to that of the vanilla distributed GCNs training without staleness. Extensive experiments show that PipeGCN can boost training throughput while achieving the same accuracy as its vanilla counterpart and outperforming existing full - graph training methods.

This paper studies the problem of test time robustification, i.e., using the test input to improve model robustness in the face of distribution shift. The authors propose a simple approach that can be used in any test setting where the model is probabilistic and adaptable : when presented with a test example, perform different data augmentations on the data point, and then adapt ( all of ) the model parameters by minimizing the entropy of the model ’s average, or marginal distribution across the augmentations, thus enforcing the invariances encoded in these augmentations and maintaining confidence in its predictions. The experiments show that this approach achieves accuracy gains of 1 - 8 % over standard model evaluation and generally outperforms prior augmentation and adaptation strategies.

This paper proposes a model - based reinforcement learning algorithm that jointly trains the model and the policy, such that updates to either component increase a lower bound on the expected return. The main contribution of this work is an algorithm, Mismatched no More ( MnM ), that provably maximizes the expected reward. This bound becomes tight at optimality under certain assumptions. The algorithm has the unique property of jointly optimizing the policy and model using the same objective.

This paper proposes a simple model combination approach inspired by human decision making. The authors first compute a coarse action based on the instantaneous observation, and then refine it into a final action using historical information. The experiments show that this outperforms all baselines on CARLA autonomous driving from images and various MuJoCo continuous control tasks.

This paper proposes a model - based meta - learning method for heterogeneous domain generalization. The proposed method is based on two parts : an encoder and a forecaster. The encoder encodes the time - invariant hidden features of the task with weak supervision, and the forecaster learns the shared dynamics of the entire domain. The authors prove that the generalization error is related to the task relatedness in the source domain, as well as the domain differences between source and target domains.

This paper proposes a novel method for weakly supervised monocular 3D object detection. The proposed method first generates 2D boxes on the image and then uses the generated 2D box to select corresponding RoI LiDAR points as the weak supervision. Then, a network is proposed to predict 3D boxes which can tightly align with associated RoI points. Extensive experiments validate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a soft gradient - based subword tokenization method to replace rigid end - to - end tokenization methods in natural language processing ( NLP ) models. The proposed method is based on a data - driven approach that learns latent subword representations from characters in a data driven fashion. Experiments are conducted on English GLUE, multilingual, and noisy text datasets to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a method for detecting backdoor attacks in black - box hard - label scenarios where only the final output label of the network is available. The proposed method is based on an adversarial extreme value analysis of the adversarial map, computed from the monte - carlo gradient estimation. Experiments on three popular tasks and backdoor attacks show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new measure for estimating in - distribution and out - of - distribution ( OOD ) uncertainty. The proposed measure is based on a Kullback - Leibler divergence criterion defined on the class - probability simplex. It captures both class confusion and lack of evidence in a single score and does not require OOD training data. An auxiliary network named KLoSNet is also proposed to learn a refined criterion directly aligned with the evidential training objective for training samples and to improve uncertainty estimation.

This paper studies a semi - supervised learning algorithm that learns a linear classifier over datadependent features from unlabeled data under some natural distributional assumptions. The main assumption is that the distribution of “ important ” patches in the input images has a low - dimensional structure ( e.g., the patches are sampled from a low dimensional manifold ). Under this assumption, the authors show that the algorithm provably learns CNNs under the distributional assumption. The authors also provide a lower bound showing that the dependence of the algorithm on the dimension of the patch distribution is essentially optimal.

This paper proposes a novel algorithm for face clustering based on Graph Convolutional Networks ( GCN ). The key idea is to construct clean graphs by constructing clean graphs for GCNs by considering face features of the neighbour images. Then, an adaptive neighbour discovery strategy is proposed to determine a proper number of edges connecting to each face image. Experiments on multiple public clustering datasets show that Ada - NETS significantly outperforms current state - of - the - art methods.

This paper proposes a new method for distributionally robust optimization ( DRO ) for generalizable person re - identification ( DG ReID ). The authors propose a simple yet efficient approach that minimizes the loss over a reweighted dataset where important samples ( i.e. models on which models perform poorly ) will be upweighted and others will be downweighted. Empirical results show that the proposed method achieves superior performance on large - scale DG Re ID and cross - domain ReID benchmarks compared to standard baselines.

This paper proposes a simple yet effective method to improve the performance of graph neural networks ( GNNs ) on 3D molecular property prediction tasks. The main idea is to corrupt the input graph with noise and add a noise correcting node - level loss to improve oversmoothing. The paper shows that the noise correction loss helps ameliorate over - smoothing by encouraging diverse node latents. Experiments show that the proposed method outperforms existing methods on three different tasks.

This paper studies the problem of learning a vector representation from an input set of a variable number of feature vectors. The key idea is to use a mixture distribution to estimate the i.i.d samples from the input set and then use the maximum - a - posterior ( MAP ) steps of the feed - forward network to learn the set embedding. The proposed method is evaluated on several tasks in bioinformatics and NLP and shows improved performance over state - of - the - art methods.

This paper proposes a method for performing feature selection in contrastive contrastive analysis ( CA ). The proposed method is based on contrastive feature selection, where the objective is to select a small number of informative features for use in unknown downstream tasks. The method is evaluated on a semi - synthetic dataset and four real - world biomedical datasets and it consistently outperforms standard unsupervised feature selection algorithms.

This paper studies the relationship between optimal early stopping time and model dimension as well as sample size of the dataset for certain linear regression models. The authors demonstrate two very different behaviors when the model dimension exceeds the number of features versus the opposite scenario. They demonstrate experimentally that their theoretical results on optimal early stop time corresponds to the training process of deep neural network. They also demonstrate the effect of early stopping on generalization.

This paper proposes a quasi - Newton method for the policy gradient algorithm with entropy regularization in reinforcement learning problems. The main idea is to take the geometry of the problem into consideration and take the Newton method, for example, preconditions the gradient with the Hessian matrix and obtains second - order local convergence. Experiments on synthetic and industrial - scale examples show that the proposed method typically converges in single - digit iterations, often orders of magnitude faster than other state - of - the - art algorithms.

This paper proposes a generalization method for text - based games ( TBGs ) based on case - based reasoning to generalize out of the training distribution. The proposed method collects instances of positive experiences from the agent ’s interaction with the world in the past and later reuses the collected experiences to act efficiently. The method can be applied in conjunction with any existing on - policy neural agent in the literature for TBGs. The experiments show that the proposed approach consistently improves existing methods and achieves new state - of - the - art results on the TextWorld Commonsense dataset.

This paper proposes a two - stage method to distill multiple word senses from a pre - trained contextual language model ( BERT ) by using attention over the senses of a word in a context and transferring this sense information to fit multi - sense embeddings in a skip - gram - like framework. Experiments on the contextual word similarity and sense induction tasks show that this method is superior to state - of - the - art methods in terms of word similarity.

This paper studies the transfer of 2D model architectures and weights to understand 3D point - clouds. The authors show that they can indeed use the same architecture and pretrained weights of a neural net model to understand both images and point-clouds. Specifically, they transfer the image - pretrained model to a point cloud model by inflating 2D convolutional filters and finetuning the inflated imagepretrained models ( FIP ). The results show that FIP improves data efficiency, reaching up to 10.0 points top - 1 accuracy gain on few - shot classification.

This paper proposes a method for training autoregressive generative models that takes advantage of a well - designed energy - based learning objective. The method is capable of alleviating the exposure bias problem and increase temporal coherence by imposing a constraint which fits joint distributions at each time step. The proposed method is evaluated on tasks like language modeling, neural machine translation, and image generation.

This paper presents a unified framework that connects Wasserstein distributional robustness with current state - of - the - art AT methods. Theoretically, the proposed framework encompasses the DR versions of the SOTA AT methods and proves that these AT methods are special cases of their DR counterparts. Practically, motivated by the theoretical study, the authors develop a novel family of algorithms that generalize the AT methods in the standard robustness setting. Extensive experiments show that the proposed algorithms robustify further their standard AT counterparts in various settings.

This paper proposes a novel unsupervised representation learning framework for multivariate time series. The proposed method is based on instance - level augmentation by simply applying dropout on the entire time series for better preserving global context and capturing long - term dependencies. An iterative bilinear temporal - spectral fusion module is devised to explicitly encode the affinities of abundant time - frequency pairs and iteratively refine representations of time series through cross - domain interactions with Spectrum - to - Time ( S2T ) and Timeto - Spectrum ( T2S ) Aggregation modules. Extensive experiments are conducted on three major practical tasks for time series such as classification, forecasting and anomaly detection.

This paper proposes a method for automatically adjusting the learning rate during gradient descent. The learning rate is trained along with the model weights, akin to line - search. Learning rate is optimized via a simple extra gradient descent step, justified by an analysis that exploits the structure of neural networks. The authors formulate first and second - order gradients with respect to learning rate as functions of consecutive weight gradients, leading to a cost - effective implementation. Extensive experimental evaluation is conducted, validating the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a continual meta - RL method for sequential multi - task learning, where the agent has access to all tasks during training but is not allowed to revisit previous tasks to collect data. The proposed method is based on meta - training in an incremental fashion, over each task in a sequence, without revisiting prior tasks. Two subroutines : learning a new task using RL and using the experience from RL to perform completely offline meta - learning to prepare for subsequent task learning are proposed. The experiments show that the proposed method outperforms prior methods on several sequences of challenging continuous control tasks.

This paper proposes a new threat model for poisoned classifiers, where one without knowledge of the original trigger would want to control the poisoned classifier. Under this threat model, the authors propose a test - time, human - in - the - loop attack method to generate multiple effective alternative triggers without access to the initial backdoor and the training data. Experiments on high - resolution datasets show that the proposed method is more scalable and efficient in generating effective triggers.

This paper studies the output discrepancy issue in the unconditional GAN distillation problem, where the teacher and student model yield different outputs given the same input latent code. The authors conduct thorough analysis about the reasons and effects of this discrepancy issue, and identify that the style module plays a vital role in determining semantic information of generated images. Based on this finding, the authors propose a novel initialization strategy for the student model, which can ensure the output consistency to the maximum extent. Extensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach in distilling StyleGAN2.

This paper introduces a general methodology for approximating offline algorithms in online settings by encoding the behavior of offline algorithms into graphs and training a multi - task learning model to simultaneously detect behavioral structures which have already occurred and predict those that may come next. The methodology is demonstrated on both synthetic data and historical stock market data, where the contrast between explanation and prediction is particularly stark. This work represents the first general and end - to - end differentiable approach for generating online approximations for offline algorithms.

This paper proposes a method to reduce the number of inducing points in Gaussian processes ( GP ) by amortizing the parameters of an approximate posterior distribution. The inducing points are learned by considering them as parameters of the approximate posterior of the posterior distribution for the outputted inducing points. The method uses a neural network that receives the observed data as an input and outputs the inducing points locations and the parameters. Experiments show that the proposed method performs similar or better than state - of - the - art sparse variational GP approaches.

This paper proposes a protocol for secure ( byzantinetolerant ) decentralized training that emphasizes communication efficiency. The authors provide theoretical bounds for its resistance against Byzantine and Sybil attacks and demonstrate its practical effectiveness in large - scale experiments on image classification and language modeling in presence of Byzantine attackers.

This paper studies the problem of learning physics - informed particle hydrodynamics ( PIML ). The authors present a learn - able hierarchy of parameterized and “ physics - explainable ” SPH - informed fluid simulators using both physics based parameters and Neural Networks as universal function approximators. They show that their method is capable of solving inverse problems over the physically interpretable parameter space, as well as over the space of Neural Network parameters and Lagrangian statistics of turbulence. Furthermore, their method gradually introduces more physical structure, which improves interpretability, generalizability, preservation of physical symmetries, and requires less training data.

This paper proposes an approach to regularize a single deterministic neural network to obtain improved accuracy and reliable uncertainty estimates. The proposed approach simply puts an entropy maximization regularizer corresponding to the predictive distribution in the regions of the embedding space between the class clusters. This is achieved by synthetically generating between - cluster samples via the convex combination of two images from different classes and maximizing the entropy on these samples. Such a data - dependent regularization guides the maximum likelihood estimation to prefer a solution that maps out - of - distribution samples to high entropy regions ( creating an entropy barrier ) and is more robust to superficial input perturbations.

This paper proposes a self - supervised auto - encoder for animating still images by directly manipulating the latent space of a deep generative model. The key idea is to learn a set of orthogonal motion directions simultaneously, and use their linear combination, in order to represent any displacement in latent space. The experimental results show that the proposed method outperforms state - of - the - art methods on VoxCeleb, Taichi and TED - talk datasets w.r.t generated quality.

This paper proposes a task augmentation method ( MLTI ) that densifies the task distribution by introducing additional tasks. Theoretical analysis shows that MLTI corresponds to a data - adaptive meta - regularization and further improves the generalization. Empirically, in eight real - world datasets from various domains, MLTI consistently outperforms six prior metalearning regularization methods and is compatible with six representative meta - learning algorithms.

This paper proposes a new approach for fair representation learning based on normalizing flows. The idea is to model the encoder as a normalizing flow trained to minimize the statistical distance between the latent representations of different groups. The main advantage of FNF is that its exact likelihood computation allows us to obtain guarantees on the maximum unfairness of any potentially adversarial downstream predictor. Experiments are conducted on a variety of datasets to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

This paper proposes a novel graph neural network ( GNN ) for subgraph isomorphism counting. The key idea is to learn a low - dimensional representation for both the query and the input graph, in order to predict the number of sub - graph isomorphisms. At the edge level, they resort to an edge - centric message passing scheme, where messages on edges are propagated and aggregated based on the edge adjacency. Moreover, they design an query - conditioned graph modulation to adapt structure matching to different queries from the graph perspective.

This paper studies the problem of federated personalized personalized learning, where local participants have their own personalized labels, which might not be compatible with others ( even for the same class ) and can be from a variety of multiple domains. The authors propose a novel method, namely Similarity Matching and Kernel Factorization ( SimFed ), which measures task - level similarity based on locally learned knowledge and matches the relevant ones for personalized knowledge reflection. The method is evaluated on both single and multi - domain datasets and shows that it outperforms the current state - of - the - art baselines.

This paper proposes a novel method for object - centric scene representation based on object dynamics. The key idea is to extract object dynamics ( e.g., velocity ) from raw video input and distill it into explicit object dynamic representations. The method is evaluated on video understanding tasks of video events reasoning and video prediction.

This paper studies the problem of node - set - based link prediction in graph neural networks ( GNNs ). The authors propose a class of GNN layers called positional encoding layers ( PEG ) that allow using positional features of nodes given by positional encoding ( PE ) techniques such as Laplacian Eigenmap and Deepwalk. Extensive link prediction experiments over 8 real - world networks demonstrate the advantages of PEG in generalization and scalability.

This paper proposes a novel method for text style transfer based on large - scale language models. The method first mines the roughly parallel expressions in the non - parallel datasets with scene graphs, and then employs MLE training, followed by imitation learning refinement, to leverage the intrinsic parallelism within the data. The proposed method is evaluated on two benchmark tasks (sentiment & formality transfer ) and a newly proposed challenging task ( political stance transfer ).

This paper studies the problem of multi - hop logical reasoning on hyper - relational knowledge graphs ( KGs ). In particular, the authors propose a method to answer conjunctive queries in the context of Graph Neural Networks ( GNNs ). The proposed method is based on the idea of embedding query embeddings in the latent space of the graph. Experiments are conducted to validate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a method for hyperparameter optimization in a gray - box setting. The main idea is to learn to dynamically decide which configuration to try next, and for what budget. The method is based on a new surrogate for Gaussian Processes that embeds the learning curve dynamics and a new acquisition function that incorporates multi - budget information. The results show that the proposed method outperforms state - of - the - art methods on a number of benchmark datasets.

This paper studies the problem of cross - platform consistency in learned image compression. The authors propose to solve this problem by introducing well - developed post - training quantization and making the model inference integer - arithmetic - only. They further improve the discretization of the entropy parameters and extend the deterministic inference to fit Gaussian mixture models.

This paper proposes a fully unsupervised noise reconstruction and removal network for denoising scanning electron microscopy images. The architecture, inspired by gated recurrent units, reconstructs and removes the noise by synthesizing the sequential data. At the same time, the training guides the network in distinguishing true signal from noise and gives comparable / even better results than supervised approaches on 3D electron microscope data sets.

This paper studies the label trick in graph neural networks ( GNNs ). In particular, the authors propose to use a randomly - selected portion of the training labels as GNN inputs, concatenated with the original node features for making predictions on the remaining labels. This so - called label trick accommodates the parallel use of features and labels, and is foundational to many of the top - ranking submissions on the Open Graph Benchmark ( OGB ) leaderboard. The authors prove that under certain simplifying assumptions, the stochastic label trick can be reduced to an interpretable, deterministic training objective composed of two factors. The first is a data - fitting term that naturally resolves potential label leakage issues, while the second serves as a regularization factor conditioned on graph structure that adapts to graph size and connectivity.

This paper studies the problem of modeling theory of mind ( ToM ) in a multi - agent environment where agents can speak, listen, see other agents, and move freely through a grid world. The authors propose to model the problem in a more flexible and symmetric scenario where all agents are able to speak, see, and interact with each other agents. They show that the best agents fail to achieve performance comparable to agents with access to the gold - standard mental state of other agents with no such ToM model. They also show that SymmToM can be completely solved neither by using well - known RL models nor tailoring those models to our task.

This paper proposes a novel method for zero - shot object detection based on the YCB Video dataset. The proposed method is based on YOLOv5 and is able to detect novel objects in the image with the knowledge learned from and only from seen objects. The authors also propose a splitting method to split the dataset by seen and unseen objects and a novel attribute labelling method.

This paper proposes a method to train a latent video prediction model that is capable of predicting high - fidelity future frames with minimal modification to existing models and produce high - resolution (256x256 ) videos. Specifically, the proposed method scales up prior models by employing a high - fidelity image generator ( VQ - GAN ) with a causal transformer model, and introduce additional techniques of top - k sampling and data augmentation to further improve video prediction quality. The proposed method achieves competitive performance to state - of - the - art approaches on standard video benchmarks with fewer parameters and enables high resolution video prediction on complex and large - scale datasets.

This paper proposes a method for training generative adversarial networks ( GANs ) with vision transformers ( ViTs ). The main idea is to use the latent and pixel mapping layers of ViTs to regularize the GAN discriminators. The method is evaluated on image generation tasks on CIFAR-10, CelebA, and LSUN bedroom. The results show that the proposed method is competitive with existing methods.

This paper studies the problem of image generative modeling with variational autoencoders. The authors propose a two - stage training process that trains a secondary high - rate model on top of the low - rate models to improve the ELBO. The secondary model is restricted to modeling visually imperceptible information and it can improve the sample quality significantly with minimal impact on the initial low - rates model.

This paper proposes a training - free inference framework to estimate the analytic forms of the reverse variance and optimal KL divergence of a Diffusion Probabilistic Model ( DPM ) using Monte Carlo method and a pretrained score - based model. The proposed framework is applicable to a variety of DPMs and consistently improves the log - likelihood of these models. Empirically, the proposed framework also consistently improves sample quality and requires up to 50 timesteps to achieve a comparable FID to the corresponding baseline.

This paper studies the performance of vision transformers ( ViTs ) in medical image classification tasks. Specifically, the authors conduct a series of experiments on several standard medical image benchmark datasets and tasks. They show that, while CNNs perform better if trained from scratch, off - the - shelf vision transformer models can perform on par with CNNs when pretrained on ImageNet, both in a supervised and self - supervised setting.

This paper shows that pretraining neural language models ( NLMs ) over a large corpus involves chunking the text into training examples, which are contiguous text segments of sizes processable by the neural architecture. The authors show that the pretrained NLMs can model much stronger dependencies between text segments that appeared in the same training example, than it can between different training examples. This intuitive result formalizes the motivation behind a broad line of recent successful NLM training heuristics, proposed for the pretraining and fine - tuning stages, which do not necessarily appear related at first glance. The result clearly indicates further improvements to be made in NLM pretraining for the benefit of Natural Language Understanding tasks.

This paper proposes a new method for learning to optimize ( L2O ) based on symbolic regression. The main contribution of the paper is the introduction of symbolic regression to improve the scalability and interpretability of the proposed method. The paper also introduces a lightweight re - parameterization to enable fine - tuning of the symbolic rules. The proposed method is able to be meta - trained on large - scale problems and outperforms human - designed and tuned optimizers.

This paper studies the problem of provable robustness against adversarial attacks in reinforcement learning. The main contribution of the paper is the use of policy smoothing to certify the total reward without requiring the policy to be robust at each time - step. The proposed method is based on the Neyman - Pearson Lemma. Theoretical results show that the proposed method can provide provable lower bounds on the average performance of the defended agents, against any adversary.

This paper proposes a method for predicting the target domain accuracy using only labeled source data and unlabeled target data.
